Deze ooit adellijke landgoederen zijn nu de thuisbasis van lizardfolk, ondoden, en erger. De grootste bedreiging voor schattenjagers is de {@creature ancient black dragon} tweeling Voaraghamanthar en Waervaerendor. Terwijl de eerste beschouwd wordt als de onbetwiste Heer van de Vlakte, is de tweede nauwelijks bekend en de twee draken vinden het prima zo.
Als de personages de Mere verkennen, gebruik dan de {@filter Swamp Monsters|bestiary|environment=swamp} tabel in appendix B van de {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} om ideeën voor ontmoetingen op te doen.

entries.name: Mintarn
entries: Mintarn is lang een neutraal gebied geweest voor verschillende machten, een plek ver weg van de conflicten van de kuststaten en de rivaliteit van de Noordelijke eilanden. Elk schip, of het nu een piraat, een kaper of een koopvaarder was, kon aanmeren in Mintarn en een warm welkom vinden. Vele verdragen werden aan de kust gesloten, en wanneer er geen vrede kon worden bereikt, verhuurden soldaten en schepen van Mintarn zich aan verschillende machtsgroepen, zonder bang te hoeven zijn voor vergelding in eigen land.

Nog niet zo lang geleden werd Mintarn overspoeld met munten dankzij Dagult Neverember's scheepsbouwbedrijf White Sails, en zijn munten vloeiden door Waterdeep nadat hun marine was verspild aan het jagen op piraten. Bovendien begon Neverember Tarniaanse huurlingen in te huren om de gelederen van de Neverwinter Watch te vullen.

Helaas wekte het gewicht van het goud op het eiland Hoondarrh-de Rode Draak van Mintarn, een oude rode draak aan wie de noordlanders jaarlijks eer betoonden. Hoondarrh wilde de jaarlijkse tiende verhogen en verwoestte Kasteel Mintarn om zijn punt te maken. Het volk van Mintarn haastte zich om aan de eisen van de ongeduldige wyrm te voldoen en kon weinig doen om hem te weerstaan, aangezien hun soldaten in buitenlandse legers dienden. Sinds die noodlottige dag, en Neverember's verbanning uit Waterdeep, is het niet goed gegaan met Mintarn. De plaats heeft nog steeds genoeg gezellige herbergen en een overvloed aan groene wijn, maar de inwoners beginnen wanhopig te worden.

De huidige Tiran van Mintarn is Bloeth Embuirhan (LN vrouwelijk Chondathan mens {@creature gladiator} met 90 hit points) die tegen de verwachtingen in probeert Hoondarrh tevreden te houden. De draak leeft op een berg genaamd Skadaurak die oprijst uit de oceaan ten noorden van Mintarn. Zijn eerbetonen worden achtergelaten op een zandstrand in een zeegrot. Veel meer grotten verspreiden zich vanuit de tiende grot, en het gesnurk van de Rode Rage weerklinkt overal.
De personages kunnen op Mintarn terechtkomen als ze de Zoektocht van Len-jes accepteren in {@area chapter 2|nwqlq|x}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters mogen proberen de grote schat van Hoondarrh te plunderen tijdens hun bezoek aan Mintarn. Er doen geruchten de ronde over de schatten die in zijn hol op Skadaurak liggen, waaronder een magische parel die veroudering tegengaat, een dozijn menselijke schedels van massief robijn, en een levensgrote draak die volledig van goud is gemaakt. De lokale bevolking beweert ook dat de Rode Woede het grootste deel van het jaar slaapt. Hij ontwaakt alleen als het tijd is om eerbetoon van de Tarniërs te ontvangen.

Personages die zich op Skadaurak wagen, ontdekken dat het eiland een uitgeholde berg is met verschillende zeegrotten die toegang geven op oceaanniveau. Er is geen teken van de draak, noch van zijn schat, vanaf de buitenkant. De personages die de zeegrotten betreden horen het langzame opkomen en neergaan van Hoondarrh's gesnurk, een gestaag ritme dat de personages waarschuwt voor het ontwaken van de draak. Hoondarrh heeft zijn hol doorzeefd met een verscheidenheid aan valstrikken, zowel eenvoudige als complexe, altijd dodelijk. Gebruik de {@filter examples|trapshazards|type=!ENV;!GEN;!HAZ;!WTH;!WLD} in hoofdstuk 5 van de {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} en hoofdstuk 2 van {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything} om de verdedigingswerken van het hol te inspireren. Als de personages op verkenning gaan en telkens als ze een val activeren, moeten ze een DC 26 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check maken om te voorkomen dat Hoondarrh wakker wordt. Als de personages er drie keer niet in slagen, stopt Hoondarrh met snurken en begint hij te ontwaken.

De personages hebben {@dice 1d4 + 1} rondes om te ontsnappen voordat Hoondarr wakker wordt en hen opzoekt. Als de personages vijf vallen passeren zonder de draak te wekken, mogen ze zijn voorraad plunderen. Rol op de {@table Treasure Hoard: Challenge 17+} tabel in hoofdstuk 7 van de {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} om te bepalen wat ze vinden.

Hoondarrh is een oeroude draak, geobsedeerd door het verlengen van zijn leven, wat de reden is voor zijn lange sluimering. Hij vindt het heerlijk om avonturiers naar zijn hol te lokken en ze in stukken te zien vallen. Hij bewaakt zijn voorraad en hol met zijn leven, want als hij de controle over Mintarn verliest, verliest hij al zijn rijkdom. {@creature Hoondarrh|CallfromtheDeep} is een {@creature ancient red dragon} met de volgende {@footnote additional features|Included in the linked statblock.} die zijn uitdagingswaarde verhogen tot 25 (75.000 XP).

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Hoondarrh heeft een magische smaragd genaamd Ongild (die functioneert als een {@item ring of regeneration} en hem de eigenschap Innate Spellcasting geeft) ingebed in zijn geschubde huid, hij draagt een {@item rod of lordly might}, en hij draagt een {@item ring of feather falling}.

items.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Hoondarrh's tovervaardigheid is Charisma (magic save DC 22; {@hit +10} to hit with spell attacks). Hij kan van nature de volgende spreuken uitspreken, waarvoor hij geen materiële componenten nodig heeft:

items: 1/dag elk: {@spell delayed blast fireball}, {@spell prismatic spray}, {@spell reverse gravity}

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: Hoondarrh is een 14e level spellcaster. Zijn tovervaardigheid is Intelligentie (spell save DC 20; {@hit 12} om te raken met spell aanvallen). Hij heeft de volgende tovenaarsspreuken voorbereid:

items: Cantrip (naar believen): {@spell blade ward}, {@spell mending}, {@spell message}, {@spell ray of frost}
1e niveau (4 slots): {@spell alarm}, {@spell mage armor|phb|mage armour}, {@spell magic missile}, {@spell shield}
2e niveau (3 slots): {@spell arcane lock}, {@spell darkness}, {@spell detect thoughts}
3e niveau (3 slots): {@spell counterspell}, {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell haste}
4e niveau (3 slots): {@spell banishment}, {@spell greater invisibility}, {@spell stoneskin}
5e niveau (2 slots): {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell wall of force}
6e niveau (1 slot): {@spell flesh to stone}, {@spell globe of invulnerability}
7e niveau (1 slot): {@spell symbol}, {@spell teleport}

entries.name: Mirabar
entries: Mirabar is verreweg de rijkste stad van het Noorden. De stad ligt op een heuvel aan de noordkant van de rivier de Mirar als een onaantastbaar fort, aan alle kanten omringd door schuine buitenmuren die aan de basis even breed zijn als vele stadsblokken in Waterdeep. Verdedigers kunnen pijlen afvuren van bovenop de muren of, in de winter, water naar beneden gieten om ijsglijbanen te maken. Er is geen tekort aan steen en wapentuig. Zelfs de dokken hebben kantelen en versterkingen.

Bezoekers van Mirabar vragen zich vaak af waarom ze niet meer dwergen zien, aangezien mensen de meerderheid van de oppervlaktebewoners van de stad vormen. Een andere stad ligt net onder de oppervlakte en die plaats wordt gedomineerd door dwergen. Ondergronds is Mirabar een stad van verlichte woongrotten, oververhitte smederijen, gieterijen die dag en nacht werken, en tunnels die naar de mijnen leiden.

De maarschalk van de stad, Selin Ramur (LN mannelijk Damaran mens {@creature noble}), ontmoet de andere leden van de Lords' Alliance om ervoor te zorgen dat de belangen van Mirabar niet worden genegeerd door andere leden. Terwijl de marsion het buitenlands beleid behandelt, ligt de echte macht binnen de stad bij de Raad van de Sprankelende Stenen. Deze groep dwergoudsten regelt de veiligheid in Mirabar en beslist waar de opbrengst van de mijnen van de stad wordt verkocht. De verdediging van de stad is in handen van de Bijl van Mirabar, een elite, goed bewapend schilddwergen garnizoen. Een {@creature axe of mirabar soldier|skt|typical member} is een {@creature veteran}, met de {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: Een lid van de Bijl van Mirabar heeft AC 18 ({@item plate armor|phb|plate}), 67 ({@dice 9d8 + 27}) hit points, en een snelheid van 25 feet.
Zij hebben een Constitution score van 16 ({@d20 3}) en {@sense darkvision} tot een bereik van 60 voet.
Ze spreken {@language Common} en {@language Dwarvish}.
Ze hebben voordeel bij het redden van worpen tegen gif en weerstand tegen gifschade.
Zij hanteren een {@item battleaxe|phb} in plaats van een {@item longsword|phb} en een {@item handaxe|phb} in plaats van een {@item shortsword|phb}.

entries: Het ruige land rond Mirabar ligt bezaaid met mijnkoppen, open groeven, en hopen slakken en puin. De mijnen van Mirabar leveren enorme hoeveelheden van de meeste bekende metalen en edelstenen op. Werkende mijnen van enige betekenis zijn zwaar versterkt. Alle mijnwerkers, dwergen en mensen, worden voor en na hun dienst gefouilleerd om de veiligheid te garanderen. Het is een ongemak dat de mijnwerkers accepteren omdat Mirabar, in tegenstelling tot veel andere plaatsen in het Noorden, goed betaalt en zorg draagt voor de arbeiders.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: De versterkte dokken van Mirabar leggen een schip aan, genaamd de Carny. Het is bijna net zo breed als het lang is en heeft een enorme, gestreepte grote kap aan zijn dek vastgemaakt. Op een houten bord bij het schip staat: "De grootste drijvende show die je ooit zult zien! Vuurspuwen, zwaardwerpen, tijgers temmen en nog veel meer! Shows op het middaguur en in de schemering. 5 sp per kaartje, 1 sp voor kinderen."

Naast het bord staat een verfomfaaid meisje met een felgekleurde tuniek en een narrenhoed. Characters die slagen op een DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check merken een zwavelachtige geur rond haar op. Als de check slaagt met 5 of meer, merken ze een rode slijmdraad op die van haar enkel naar het schip loopt. Het meisje, dat zichzelf voorstelt als 'Little Lion', is een simulacrum gevormd door een {@creature elder oblex|mtf} die zich schuilhoudt in het ruim van The Carny. Het slijm is gemaakt door Zellix'Phor en de illithidkolonie en wordt gebruikt om Mirabar te bespioneren en slachtoffers te vangen voor de geestverruimers. Het geheugen van elk wezen dat door de oblex wordt leeggezogen, wordt telepathisch doorgegeven aan Zellix'Phor.

De shows op The Carny zijn enorm vermakelijk. Ze maken alles waar wat het bord belooft en meer, verpakt in het spectaculaire showmanschap van Belladonna Beguile, een charmante ringmeesteres die een paarse hoge hoed en staarten draagt. Voordat de show begint, kondigt Belladonna de aanwezigheid aan van Gilthur Goldfinder (LN mannelijke schilddwerg {@creature noble}), een gewaardeerd lid van de Raad van de Sprankelende Stenen. Gilthur staat voor het publiek en maakt een diepe buiging.
Personages met een passieve Wijsheid ({@skill Perception}) score van 18 of hoger merken de volgende vreemde voorvallen op gedurende de show:

items: Het vuur is een nep {@spell minor illusion} effect.
Een van de zwaard-zwaaiers lijkt in de zijkant van zijn mond te snijden, maar er spuit geen bloed uit de wond.
Een van de twee {@creature tiger|mm|tigers} in de show zwaait naar de temmers en lijkt een van hen te vangen met zijn klauwen, hoewel geen van de temmers reageert.
De hele plek ruikt naar rotte eieren.

entries: Personages met een passieve Wijsheidsscore van 23 of hoger zien slijmerige slierten uit elke artiest komen. De oblex heeft dertien performers (waaronder Belladonna en Little Lion) in zijn gevolg van simulacra, maar heeft ook tien {@creature guard|mm|guards} troepen om de orde te bewaren.

Op een bepaald moment tijdens de show neemt de oblex de Eat Memories actie via Belladonna op Gilthur. Het lijkt erop dat de dwerg een beroerte krijgt en hij wordt snel door twee van de bewakers van het schip gehaald. De volgende dag verlaat The Carny Mirabar over de rivier Mirar in de richting van de kust.

entries.name: Misty Forest
entries: Dit altijd groene woud dankt zijn naam aan de mist die vanaf de High Moor naar beneden kruipt en het bos omhult, waardoor het zelfs op de beste dagen moeilijk navigeren is. In het woud wordt gepatrouilleerd door boselven, die het woud beschermen tegen stropers. Bezoekers die de bewoners van het Nevelwoud met rust laten, en hun kampvuur klein en alleen van afgevallen takken maken, worden meestal niet gestoord.

entries.name: Mithral Hall
entries: Het voorouderlijk huis van de Battlehammer clan van schilddwergen is een haast onneembaar gewelf onder de Frost Hills, met massieve granieten deuren die de ingang afsluiten en een groot aantal geharde verdedigers die daarachter wachten. Ondanks zijn bijna mythische reputatie is Mithral Hall meer een bolwerk dan een stad, met tunnels naar andere dwergenburchten diep verborgen onder de mijnen.

Bruenor Battlehammer heeft voor de derde en laatste keer afstand gedaan van de titel Koning van Mithral Hall toen hij op weg ging om de stad Gauntlgrym terug te veroveren. Zijn uitgekozen opvolger, Dagnabbet Waybeard, regeert nu als koningin over Mithral Hall. Koningin Dagnabbet is een moedig leider en een felle krijger. Zij steunt het lidmaatschap van Mithral Hall in de Lords' Alliance.

entries.name: Moray
entries: Ten westen van Gwynneth, is Moray een land in oorlog met zichzelf. De in conflict verkerende Ffolk van Caer Moray worstelen om de havenstad open te houden zodat Dynnegall, verder landinwaarts, vitale voorraden kan ontvangen. Deze voorraden omvatten versterkingen om het hoofd te bieden aan de vele bedreigingen van het eiland: de Zwart Bloed stam van Malarwors aanbiddende weervolkeren, de reuzen van de Trollclaw Range, en de ogres en orcs van de Orcskill Mountains. De Ffolk van Moray zijn loyaal aan de Hoge Koning. Zij hopen op een terugkeer naar een verenigd Moonshaes onder het vaandel van Kendrick en zijn vastbesloten lang genoeg vol te houden om dat te zien.

Caer Moray is niet veel meer dan een ommuurde haven, waar de meeste mensen op het eiland wonen. Buiten de muren liggen talrijke vissers- en boerendorpjes, cantrevs genaamd. Veel van deze dorpen liggen in de weelderige, vruchtbare vallei van de rivier de Shannyth.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: De personages worden gezocht door Ursa Thickhide (NG vrouwelijke Illuskan mens {@creature werebear}), een lid van de Smaragden Enclave die een queeste voor hen heeft. Zij en vier anderen zijn naar het eiland gestuurd om de Moonwells, een poel met heilig water, te beschermen tegen de Black Blood Tribe, die in deze poel mensen offeren in een poging een aspect van {@deity Malar|Faerûnian|scag} op te roepen. De groep werd misleid door een jakhals en naar een doodlopende pas geleid, waar ze werden overvallen door een bende lycanthropen. Usra wist te ontsnappen, maar de anderen werden gedood, althans dat dacht ze. In de afgelopen dagen kwam Warpip, een eekhoorn van Ellawick Gnackle, vanuit het bos naar Ursa en bracht het nieuws dat Ellawick gevangen zat in een kamp van de Zwartbloeden in de Trollclaw Range, op een halve dag lopen van Caer Moray.

Als de personages Ursa en de Smaragden Enclave willen helpen, kunnen ze met de weerbeer meereizen naar het kampement van de Zwartbloeden, dat niet veel meer is dan een houten hut en een half dozijn tenten, omringd door een inderhaast opgetrokken palissademuur. In het kamp zijn vier {@creature werewolf|mm|werewolves}, twee {@creature jackalwere|mm|jackalweres} die de gevangenen in de hut bewaken, en {@creature Rugrig Foamtankard|CallfromtheDeep}, een {@creature wereboar} met de {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.} die zijn uitdagingswaarde verhoogt tot 5 (1.800 XP):

items: Rugrig draagt {@item spiked armor|scag|spiked armour} (AC 14 in humanoïde vorm).
Rugrig heeft 120 hit points.

Rugrig hanteert {@item clawed gauntlet|CallfromtheDeep|clawed gauntlets} in plaats van een {@item maul|phb}: {@hit 5} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doelwit, waarbij hij 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) doordringende schade toebrengt. Als Rugrig aanvalt met de handschoen, kan hij een extra handschoenaanval doen als bonusactie. Een karakter dat bedreven is met {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} wordt beschouwd als bedreven met de handschoen.
Rugrig draagt een {@item periapt of wound closure}.

entries: In de hut zitten vijf gevangenen; Ellawick Gnackle (vrouwelijke boskabouter CG {@creature druid}), Rhydian Morgan (mannelijke Ffolk mens LG {@creature commoner}), en drie {@creature orc|mm|orcs} genaamd Urzul (mannelijke), Shamog (mannelijke), en Baggi (vrouwelijke). Elk zit opgesloten in een houten kooi met een hangslot. Rugrig heeft de sleutels van elke kooi. De sloten kunnen worden opengebroken met een succesvolle DC 10 Dexterity check {@item thieves' tools|phb}, of worden opengebroken (AC 15, 30 hit points). Elk geluid waarschuwt de omringende wezens. Elke schade die groter is dan de hit points van de kooi wordt overgedragen op de gevangene binnenin. De gevangenen worden onderdrukt door de Sleep Gaze van de jackalwere bewakers. Als een personage de gevangenis in de gaten houdt en slaagt voor een DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, hoort hij de jakhalzen praten over het opofferen van de gevangenen morgen.

De volgende dag worden de gevangenen op een kar geladen, getrokken door een gevangen {@creature aurochs|vgm} die aan de orcs toebehoort, en naar een Maanbron drie uur verderop gebracht. Tenzij de personages tussenbeide komen, worden ze daar één voor één geofferd, waardoor het glinsterende water van de vijver dieprood kleurt en de Black Bloods in de gelegenheid worden gesteld om te communiceren met {@deity Malar|Faerûnian|scag}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Elk weerwolflid van de Zwartbloedstam draagt {@dice 2d10} gp in een buidel. Rugrig draagt een electrum {@item signet ring|phb} (ter waarde van 50 gp) met het berenpoot symbool van {@deity Malar|Faerûnian|scag}.

entries.name: Murann
entries: Murann, de Stad van de Matroos, is de op één na grootste stad van Amn. De stad ligt aan het westelijke einde van de Tethir Road in de Tarseth Bay. De economie van de stad is volledig gebaseerd op de handel over zee, en goederen reizen in beide richtingen tussen de stad tot aan het continent Maztica. De stad wordt voornamelijk bewoond door kooplieden, scheepstimmerlieden en de Havenwacht die de haven verdedigt tegen piraten en het Schaduw Dievengilde dat vanuit Amn opereert. De stad wordt geregeerd door een parlement van koopmansfamiliehoofden, die ervoor proberen te zorgen dat de haven te allen tijde open blijft en de handel stevig in Muranni-gunst blijft. De families in het parlement zijn de Hirehooks, de Nubaedfyd, de Kaptonnemes, de Luraxxol, de Ophals, en de Tuskar.

Dankzij de havenwacht is Murann een relatief veilige stad om te bezoeken. De grootste gevaren voor de bevolking zijn de altijd aanwezige Schaduwdieven die overal in Amn criminaliteit organiseren, en de stammen ogres, aangevoerd door machtige oni, die aanvallen vanuit de Tejarn Heuvels ten oosten van de stad.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: De eerste keer dat de personages de stad binnenkomen, ontdekken ze dat de haven wordt aangevallen door een sentient {@item galleon|CallfromtheDeep} genaamd {@item Dreadcutter|CallfromtheDeep}. Het galjoen is voorzien van wapentuig en wappert met een zwarte wimpel. Dreadcutter is een chaotisch kwaadaardig schip met een intelligentie van 16, een wijsheid van 10 en een charisma van 18. Het heeft een gehoor tot een afstand van 120 voet. Het schip kan gewone taal spreken en lezen, en telepathisch communiceren met elk wezen binnen een straal van 120 meter, op een kwaadaardige, snauwerige toon. Dreadcutter is arrogant en egoïstisch, en wil niets liever dan het meest gevreesde piratenschip aan de Zwaardkust worden. Het schip ontstond toen een drow tovenaar zich van het leven beroofde aan boord van het galjoen. Haar ziel blijft in het schip hangen, maar heeft geen herinnering aan haar leven.

Dreadcutter is een magisch, voelend bouwsel. Het heeft AC 15, 300 hit points, en een schadedrempel van 20. Het is uitgerust met twee {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, een {@object mangonel}, en een {@object ram}, en kan één aanval doen met elk per beurt. Een karakter kan zich afstemmen op de Dreadcutter en ermee communiceren alsof het een wapen met gevoel is, maar de Dreadcutter probeert de controle over zijn drager over te nemen als hij niet minstens één schip per keer laat zinken.

Dreadcutter werd door Zeekoning Tentrix ingehuurd om Murann aan te vallen als onderdeel van het Zwaardkustoffensief. Een personage dat zich op Dreadcutter afstemt, kan deze informatie van het schip krijgen, zolang hij de wensen van Dreadcutter opvolgt. Als de personages niet tussenbeide komen, vernietigt de Dreadcutter het grootste deel van de zeemacht van Murann alvorens op te stijgen in de richting van Asavir's Kanaal. Als hij vertrekt, klinkt het geluid van hard gekakel in de wind.

entries.name: Narino
entries: Narino is een verlaten stad van zeemeermensen ten zuiden van Mintarn. De zeemeermensen daar waren ooit een genootschap van rijke kooplieden die parels en koraal verhandelden aan de Tarniërs, maar ook aan Waterdhaviaanse en Neverwintiaanse kooplieden. Maar na de val van Mintarn raakte de nederzetting in verval. Zonder handel vertrokken meer en meer zeelieden.

Tot overmaat van ramp liet een schip dat boven Narino voer een kist van zwart mahoniehout overboord vallen die op de onderwatermarkt terechtkwam. De kist bevatte Mei Ling, een vampier die zich snel aanpaste aan haar nieuwe onderwateromgeving. Zij voedde zich gulzig met de overgebleven zeemeermensen en veranderde de stad in haar hol.
Personages kunnen in Narino terechtkomen als ze de Zoektocht van Len-jes accepteren in {@area chapter 2|nwqlq|x}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Bij het verkennen van de onderwaterstad zullen de personages zeker het grootste gebouw in de ruïnes tegenkomen: een paleis uitgehouwen uit een enorme kei bedekt met koralen en anemonen. De onderste verdiepingen van het paleis, die dienden als woonvertrekken en banketzalen, zijn voor het grootste deel ingestort, zodat alleen de bovenste verdiepingen nog open zijn. Het is hier dat de vampier Mei Ling verblijft.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Narino (Player).jpg}.}

Bovenaan een gladde, spiraalvormige gang bevindt zich een koepelvormige kamer met een galerij erboven. De kamer wordt verlicht door magisch licht dat de parels in de architraven doet glinsteren. Tientallen kleine visjes fladderen in scholen door de kamer en schaaldieren scharrelen over de vloer. Aan de muren van de galerij erboven hangt een loerende waterspuwer met fonkelende saffieren ogen.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Terwijl de personages de kamer verkennen, zwemt Mei Ling van de galerij naar beneden. De vampier stelt zich voor aan de personages en vraagt waarom ze haar bezocht hebben. Zij is een gracieuze gastvrouw, maar heeft de gewoonte de persoonlijke ruimte van mensen te betreden en lijkt nooit met haar ogen te knipperen. Mei Ling creëert liever geen vampiergebroed, maar zou dat kunnen doen als een van de personages haar bevalt.
{@creature Mei Ling|CallfromtheDeep} gebruikt de statistieken van een {@creature vampire} met de {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: Ze heeft AC 18 (natuurlijke bepantsering, {@item bracers of defense})
Ze heeft een zwemsnelheid van 30 voet.
Ze verandert in een {@creature quipper} in plaats van een {@creature bat} met behulp van haar Shapechange eigenschap.
De natuurlijke stromingen van de oceaan tellen niet als "stromend water" voor één van Mei Ling's kenmerken.
Ze gebruikt een {@item vicious greatsword}: {@hit 9} om te raken, bereik 5 ft., een schepsel, dat 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) schade toebrengt bij een treffer.

entries: Als er een gevecht uitbreekt met Mei Ling in deze kamer duiken de vier {@creature gargoyle|mm|gargoyles} (zwemsnelheid van 60 voet, vliegsnelheid 0 ft.) naar beneden van de galerij boven en helpen hun meesteres.

entries.name: Light
entries: De kamer wordt voortdurend verlicht met een permanente {@spell light} betovering zonder specifieke bron.

entries.name: Gallery
entries: Boven de hoofdkamer, op een hoogte van 30 voet, is een galerij. Niets verhindert wezens tussen de twee niveaus te zwemmen. Er zijn verschillende ramen, versperd door koraal, die uitkijken over de verwoeste stad.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters met een scherp voorwerp, zoals een {@item dagger|phb}, kunnen 10 minuten lang parels uit de wanden van de kamer prikken. Rol een {@dice d20} voor elke periode van 10 minuten, tot een maximum van {@dice 3d20}. De personages krijgen een aantal parels van 10 gp terug, gelijk aan dat resultaat. De saffieren ogen (1.000 gp per stuk) van de waterspuwers kunnen ook verwijderd worden. Dit vereist een succesvolle DC 15 Dexterity check met een scherp voorwerp. Als je faalt, breekt het saffier en is het waardeloos geworden.

entries.name: Secret Corridor
entries: Personages met een passieve Wijsheid ({@skill Perception}) score van 20 of hoger merken dat er zich bubbels verzamelen rond de architraaf van een van de verzonken bogen. Met een succesvolle DC 20 Intelligentie ({@skill Investigation}) check kan een personage de geheime deur openen door op een reeks parels te drukken waarvan de glans is afgenomen. Als de parels verwijderd zijn, kan de deur niet op deze manier geopend worden.

De deur is beveiligd met een {@spell symbol} spreuk met het effect Hopeloosheid, dat in werking treedt als een niet-ondood wezen de deur opent. De {@spell symbol} kan worden gespot met een succesvolle DC 25 Intelligentie ({@skill Investigation}) check. Als het symbool wordt geactiveerd, wordt ook een {@spell alarm} spreuk in Mei Ling's geest geactiveerd. De geheime deur aan het andere eind van de gang kan van binnenuit worden geopend zonder een controle.

entries.name: N2. Crypts

entries: De gang heeft vier deuren die naar het zuiden leiden en drie nissen aan de noordwand. Elke nis bevat een bas-reliëf van een vorstelijk zeemeermin met een weelde aan juwelen.
De volgende informatie heeft betrekking op de specifieke grafkelders, van links (west) naar rechts (oost). De stenen deuren hebben een naam, behalve de meest westelijke, waar de naam is weggekrast.

entries.name: Mei Ling's Coffin
entries: The door to this crypt is barred from the inside with three steel bars. It can be forced open with a successful DC 30 Strength check. Inside, the walls are decorated with dozens of skulls. Taking up most of the floor is a black mahogany coffin that is warded against degradation by the ocean. This is Mei Ling's resting place. Any creature other than Mei Ling who touches the coffin causes the skulls to animate and attack (use the {@creature swarm of quippers} statistics). There is a secret door in the rear of the crypt that can be spotted with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Opening the door requires a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.

entries.name: Elethera Strongcurrent's Tomb
entries: The door opens into a small chamber containing dozens of weapons and shields, and a large stone sarcophagus sculpted with scenes of battle. The weapons in the chamber are made of coral and shell and are still sharp. They include four {@item spear|phb|spears}, six {@item club|phb|clubs}, and two {@item shield|phb|shields}. The sarcophagus can be opened with a successful DC 15 Strength check. Inside is the skeleton of a merfolk holding a {@footnote {@i shield of missile catching}|This item doesn't exist, but the {@item shield of missile attraction} is the closest match. Otherwise, there are the {@item gloves of missile snaring} which can be reflavoured into a shield at your discretion.} made of an enormous scallop shell and a {@item +1 guardian spear|CallfromtheDeep|+1 spear with the Guardian property} (see {@table Special Features; What Minor Property Does It Have|dmg|chapter 7} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Mialenna Frozendepth's Tomb
entries: Growing from the walls of this chamber are dozens of oysters in a thick matt of mossy seaweed. The stone sarcophagus is decorated with streams of mother of pearl in a swirling pattern reminiscent of a whirlpool. The sarcophagus is covered with barnacles and can be opened with a successful DC 15 Strength check. Inside is the skeleton of a merfolk holding an enormous pearl which functions as a {@item crystal ball of mind reading}.

entries.name: Uthemaris Swiftwave's Tomb
entries: Hundreds of symbols cover the walls of this chamber in interlocking circles and spirals. The stone sarcophagus has different metals inlaid into it in a coiling motif. The sarcophagus is protected with an {@spell arcane lock} spell but can be opened with a successful DC 25 Strength check. Opening the sarcophagus reveals a merfolk skeleton interred with a {@item staff of withering} and a {@item circlet of blasting}. Taking either of the items causes a {@creature wraith} (with a 60 ft. swim speed) to attack the thief.
A spiral ramp leads up the side of the boulder to an empty chamber. The walls of the room have thousands of nooks cut into them, each of which holds a thin sheet of grey stone.

entries.name: Tablets
entries: Each stone sheet is inscribed with {@language primordial|phb|Aquan} runes, based on Dwarvish script. They detail the history of Narino and its peoples including their trade, worship, government, wars, and treasures. The entire collection (1,450 tablets) would take multiple trips to salvage. Each tablet weighs 5 lbs. and is worth 25 gp.

Practising his aim on wooden statues and shell shields at the far end of this room is a pallid merfolk wielding a beautifully ornamented crossbow. Hanging from hooks behind him are four more crossbows, each magnificent in its unique fashion.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When characters first enter the room Berriamo Deepcurrent, a merfolk {@creature vampire spawn} wielding an eel-like {@item +1 light crossbow}, is practising his aim on the statues. Berriamo has no loyalty to Mei Ling, who created him in a moment of weakness. The two rarely talk but cohabit out of a sense of family. Berriamo defends Narino, but doesn't rusk his life to protect Mei Ling.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hanging from hooks are a number of crossbows; a {@item heavy crossbow|phb} inlaid with mother of pearl (150 gp), a {@item light crossbow|phb} made of green crystal (75 gp), a scrimshawed {@item hand crossbow|phb} made of whalebone (125 gp), and a {@item hand crossbow of warning} made of twisted coral.
This arched corridor is supported by giant, twisted shells that serve as columns. Weaving between these is an enormous eel, whose green skin crackles with sparks.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Guarding the corridor is Mei Ling's pet {@creature giant lightning eel|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The eel attacks anyone it doesn't recognise but flees if reduced to half its hit points or less.

entries.name: Nesmé
entries: Despite a heroic effort to save the town, Nesmé fell during the War of the Silver Marches to a horde of orcs aided by an ancient white dragon named Arauthator. It was then conquered by drow until they too were forced to abandon it. Today, Nesmé lies in ruins, and monsters from the Evermoors thwart efforts to rebuild it.

The town stood on the east side of the Surbrin River, enclosed within a circular wall festooned with ballistae and catapults, and connected by a fortified bridge to a formidable castle on the west side of the river. This western bastion enclosed the docks, paddocks, and stock pens, and gave the populace a place to fall back to in the event the town was breached. Although the militia put up a good fight against the orcs, the town couldn't withstand the dragon's attacks. The castle on the western shore has partially collapsed, the bridge has been destroyed, and the town's defences have been torn down. Within the town walls, now breached in several places, are piles of debris that were once shops, taverns, inns, and festhalls. Skulls, bones, rusted armour, and broken weapons are all that remain of those killed by orc axes and the dragon's icy breath.

entries.name: Neverwinter
entries: Neverwinter is a prominent city on the Sword Coast. See chapter 2 "{@adventure Neverwinter|CallfromtheDeep|5}" or the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag|2|Neverwinter|0} for more information on this location.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Unless it has already occurred, you can run the "{@adventure Attack on Neverwinter|CallfromtheDeep|5|Attack on Neverwinter}" encounter (see chapter 2) when the characters visit the city.

entries.name: Neverwinter Wood
entries: The forest east of Neverwinter has a magical quality about it, or at least an air of mystical secrecy. Neverwinter Wood holds countless ruins and more than a few crumbling castles. The always-warm Neverwinter River, which flows out of the wood, has its source deep beneath Mount Hotenow, an active volcano in the northern reaches of the forest. The volcano last erupted some fifty years ago. Lava pouring from the mountain burned a wide swath through Neverwinter Wood, destroying everything it touched. New trees have begun to grow where the ancient ones stood, though the effect of the catastrophe is still plain to see.

entries.name: Norland
entries: North of Moray lies Norland, the stronghold of the Northlanders of the Moonshae Isles. Much has happened among the Norls of late, weakening their grip on the Moonshaes, but High King Kendrick lacks the power to capitalise on it. In recent years a Northlander woman calling herself {@creature the Storm Maiden|CallfromtheDeep} arose as a battle leader among them, which was unusual as Northlanders don't allow women to raid or fish. Said to be blessed by both {@deity Valkur|Faerûnian|scag} and {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} at her birth, the Storm Maiden gathered great numbers of Norls to her banner and it seemed she might contest the king for control of Norland. However, a decade ago, she became consumed by the power of Umberlee and she drove her followers on a mad quest to control the Sea of Swords. When she was eventually defeated, she and her ship vanished into the waves. She is known to be unable to drown, and many folk fear her return.

Rault the Wise (N male Illuskan human {@creature berserker}), King of the Norls, lost his elderly son and grandson in battles against the Storm Maiden, leaving his succession in question. He has a granddaughter of great spirit and wisdom, but in the patriarchal Northlander society, and so soon after the disastrous rise to power of the Storm Maiden, it is unthinkable that rule should fall to her. Rault rules from his castle on the eastern edge of Rogarsheim, and many jarls throughout the island bend the knee to him.

If the characters visit Rault in Rogarsheim and talk to him about the pirate attacks, he tells them that Norland has indeed been attacked many times by crews. He fears the Storm Maiden will return with a crew and try to take his throne. Rault asks the characters to track down the Storm Maiden (who is currently a Pirate Lord of Sea King Tentrix) and kill her. He suggests the characters visit {@area Oman's Isle|omans isle|x}. Although the place is swarming with giants, there is a tomb there that belongs to Thelgaar Ironhand, a powerful jarl who united the Northlanders. The cairn is said to hold magic items that could help the characters, namely a magic greatsword and an unsinkable longship. If the characters bring Rault the greatsword, they can keep the longship and anything else they find. Rault does not know that the Storm Maiden is soon to pilfer the cairn for herself.

entries.name: Oman's Isle
entries: Oman's Isle is a blasted place controlled by fomorians that hurl boulders at ships that come too close. The island is home to the ruins of the Iron Keep, once home to the island's rulers. The current ruler is Hathfell the {@creature ettin} who lairs in the Iron Keep with twelve {@creature fomorian|mm|fomorians}. The creatures attack non-giants on sight and fight to the death. They aim to corrupt a Moonwell on Oman's Isle and use it to travel to other Moonwells in the Moonshaes. This quest is aided Crughth Blacktusks, an {@creature orc claw of luthic|vgm}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters might visit Oman's Isle in search of the Cairn of Thelgarr Ironhand. The cairn is hidden in a forest, but most Norls (including {@area Rault the Wise|norland|x}) know its exact location. Although the cairn has not been breached by the giants, it is guarded day and night by two {@creature fomorian|mm|fomorians}.

When characters first arrive at the cairn, the fomorians are locked in combat with three {@creature chuul|mm|chuuls} which have been sent as a distraction by the Kraken Society. The Kraken Society members, led by the notorious Storm Maiden of Moray, accessed the cairn via a subterranean stream and are hoping to plunder its treasures.

The entrance to the cairn is a descending stair in the centre of a ring of standing stones. The stair is blocked by a huge stone which looks as if it could be rolled aside. Moving the stone requires a successful DC 15 Strength check.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Ironhand Cairn (Player).png}.}

At the bottom of the rough stone stair is an unlit chamber. Twisting roots push through the cobbled walls and the packed mud ceiling. A single exit on the southern wall leads further into the tomb. Standing either side of the door are two stone statues of northlander warriors.

entries.name: Light
entries: All chambers in the cairn are unlit.

entries.name: Statues
entries: A closer look at the statues reveals they are both clutching a wooden token in their left hand with a tree engraved upon it. Casting {@spell detect magic} on the tokens shows an aura of abjuration magic.

entries.name: Exit
entries: The exit from the chamber is protected with a {@spell glyph of warding} which can be discovered with a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Any creature crossing the threshold without a wooden token (see above) triggers the glyph, which casts {@spell spike growth} over the corridor.

Columns of white stone line the corridors of this chamber. At the far end is a shrine of the same stone, atop which lies an enormous greatsword with a blood red blade as wide as a man's palm. Rather than tapering to a point, the blade broadens into an axe-like head. The southwestern corner of the chamber has crumbled away, leaving a hole.

entries.name: Green Slime
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 10 or higher notice the ceiling of this chamber is covered with patches of {@hazard green slime} (see chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Atop the shrine is a {@item giant slayer greatsword} called Ironhand's Reckoning that carries great political weight amongst the Norls. A creature that takes the sword from the shrine hears a deafening horn blast and must make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the character takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) thunder damage and is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. On a successful save, the target takes half the damage and isn't {@condition deafened}. After the boom the shrine seems to bleed, pouring onto the floor. Five {@creature berserker} spirits with resistance to all damage and magical weapons appear within 10 feet of the character and attack.

entries.name: Hole
entries: The 5-foot-wide hole in the southwestern corner drops down 10 feet into the river in {@area i4|i4}.

This chamber is in terrible condition. The flagstones of the floor are out of place and cracked in many areas. The white stone columns are blackened with soot, as are the alcoves on the north and south walls.

entries.name: Trap
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the first flagstone of the chamber (when approached from {@area i1|i1}) is raised higher than the others. Stepping on the flagstone triggers the trap, which acts on initiative 20 and 10:

items: On initiative 20 poisonous, flammable gas fills the room from tiny holes in the columns. Characters in the chamber must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

On initiative 10, sparks appear in the alcoves and ignite the gas. Each creature in the chamber must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice a slight breeze coming from the eastern alcove. A successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check uncovers a secret door, which can be opened by twisting the back wall of the alcove.

entries.name: I4. Subterranean River
entries: Flowing through the cairn is a rapid river which crashes against its stone banks. When the characters first discover the river, read or paraphrase the following:

Wading through the river are six cloaked figures, their soddenrobes pulling at their shoulders. The leading figure carries a lantern which lights their way. As you watch, a black form unfolds from the ceiling and drops onto the figure at the rear of the party, wrapping around their head as they plunge into the icy water.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The figures are five Kraken Society {@creature spy|mm|spies} led by {@creature the Storm Maiden|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). They are searching for the magic items buried with Ironhand and are making their way toward {@area i5|i5} when they are attacked by a {@creature cloaker}. If the characters don't intervene, the cloaker kills one of the spies before being dispatched.

entries.name: River
entries: The river is {@hazard frigid water|dmg|freezing cold}, flows from west to east at a rate of 60 feet per round, and is 5-foot deep. The river is difficult terrain. Characters who fall {@condition prone} in the water are carried east by the current. The river terminates on the eastern shores of Oman's Isle but flows through several tight passages without access to air. Trudging upstream leads to a safe exit, through which the Kraken Society agents entered.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Atop the cliffs in the southwest of the crypts is the cloaker's lair. Mixed with discarded bones and clothes are a {@item potion of greater healing}, a {@item potion of climbing}, a belt with a golden buckle (25 gp) and a golden torc (100 gp).

A subterranean river flows through this chamber. The sound of it surging past echoes throughout, making it hard to hear. A stone bridge spans the river and leads to a raised dais, atop which is a sarcophagus. The stone lid of the sarcophagus is sculpted in the likeness of a northlander warrior of immense height and bulk, grasping an enormous greatsword.

entries.name: River
entries: See {@area i4|i4}. Characters have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing in this chamber.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Unless already encountered in {@area i4|i4}, the Krakenar burst into this chamber from the west on initiative 20 the round after the characters arrive. On initiative 20 the following round, the {@creature cloaker} appears. The Krakenar head to the sarcophagus and try to flee with the treasure.

entries.name: Bridge
entries: The bridge is magically trapped with a {@spell flesh to stone} spell (DC 20) which is triggered when a creature walks onto the bridge. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher notice the words 'Never the easy path' etched into the bridge on the northern side.

entries.name: Sarcophagus
entries: The lid of the sarcophagus can be lifted with a successful DC 15 Strength check. Any non-Illuskan human that moves the lid causes the body of Thelgarr Ironhand to awaken as a {@creature sword wraith commander|mtf}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The tomb contains 3,300 gp in assorted coins. Beside the skeleton of Thelgarr Ironhand is a {@item folding boat} with a dragon figurehead that cannot sink, even when reduced to 0 hit points, and a suit of {@item adamantine scale mail}.

entries.name: Orlumbor
entries: If you're looking to purchase or repair a ship, there is no better port to do so than Orlumbor. The island supplies the city-states of the Sword Coast with vessels for their navies. Waterdeep in particular relied on Orlumbor, making the island a wealthy and well-protected place in return. When Lord Neverember sank Waterdeep's navy in his fight against pirates, he arranged to hire mercenary ships to replace the force, funnelling ill-gotten proceeds into his own pockets, and leaving both the coffers and shipyards of Orlumbor high and dry. After Neverember was ousted, Waterdeep's business returned, and with it much of the isle's prosperity.

Reaching Orlumbor by ship is tricky because of the rocky, cavernous approach to the harbour. Once a ship navigates the route properly it can find a wider berth, and any damage to the visitor is happily (and cheaply) repaired by the dockworkers. The homes on Orlumbor are built into the caverns of the island, and are just as well defended as the docks that are its life's blood.

More than once down the years Waterdeep's protection has kept Orlumbor from falling to Mintarn, Luskan, Amn, or Baldur's Gate, all of which have sought to claim the island's shipyards for their own. Now, Orlumbor once again serves Waterdeep in exchange for coin, foodstuffs, and other goods from Faerûn.
Characters might visit Orlumbor should they accept {@area Selacia Cradano's Quest|bgqscq|x} in chapter 2.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: As the party approach Orlumbor they are visited by Lhammaruntosz, an ancient bronze dragon who lairs on the island. The dragon doesn't conceal her true appearance but approaches cautiously in case she is mistaken for an evil dragon. If the characters don't attack, she introduces herself as Mother Claws. She inquires why the party are visiting Orlumbor and whether they saw a ship named the Bobbing Barrel on their journey.

If the party say they are adventurers, Lhamaruntosz asks if they would do her a favour. She is the proprietor of the Scaly Eye merchant company which operates along the Sword Coast. Normally no one would dare target her ships, but recently the pirates have been more bold. While she was rescuing a crew near Luskan, she lost contact with the Bobbing Barrel. Mother Claws fears the cog must have been attacked in Asavir's Channel near the Nelanther Isles.

If they accept, she promises them 500 gp for information, plus an additional 50 gp for each crew member they recover. The crew consisted of six {@creature guard|mm|guards} led by {@creature Azzakh Norixius|CallfromtheDeep} (NG male gold dragonborn {@creature bandit captain}). Mother Claws gives the characters a blue pennant with a weeping eye on it for them to fly. This is the flag of the Scaly Eye fleet and should offer some protection against pirates. Any subsequent encounter with pirates has a {@chance 50} chance of ending early when they see the pennant and flee.

Characters searching the ocean floor of Asavir's Channel who succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check find part of the wrecked Bobbing Barrel among the mass of sunken ships there. It was sunk by the Curse of Irphong (see the "{@area Asavir's Channel|asavirs channel|x}" section) and the crew were taken to Driftwood Docks via the Sea Tower of Irphong.

{@creature Lhammaruntosz|CallfromtheDeep} is an {@creature ancient bronze dragon}, with the following {@footnote additional features|Included in the linked statblock.} which increase her challenge rating to 25 (75,000 XP):

items.name: Regeneration
entries: Lhammaruntosz regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn. Lhammaruntosz only dies if she starts her turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate. This trait doesn't function in an {@spell antimagic field}.

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Lhammaruntosz carries an altered {@item lhammaruntosz's wand of fireballs|CallfromtheDeep|wand of fireballs} that deals acid  instead of fire damage.

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: Lhammaruntosz is a 12th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 21, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks). She has the following sorcerer spells prepared:

items: Cantrips (at will): {@spell acid splash}, {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell light}, {@spell mage hand}, {@spell mending}, {@spell true strike}
1st level (4 slots): {@spell comprehend languages}, {@spell expeditious retreat}
2nd level (3 slots): {@spell darkness}, {@spell detect thoughts}, {@spell suggestion}
3rd level (3 slots): {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell tongues}
4th level (3 slots): {@spell dimension door}, {@spell stoneskin}
5th level (2 slots): {@spell cloudkill}, {@spell dominate person}
6th level (1 slot): {@spell arcane gate}

entries.name: Phandalin
entries: In the northern foothills of the Sword Mountains lies the nondescript mining settlement of Phandalin. Although the village might not look like much, it provides a haven for adventurers eager to explore the surrounding wilderness, which is home to ruins and abandoned dwarven mines.
A map of Phandalin appears in the {@adventure Lost Mine of Phandelver|lmop|2|Town Description} adventure in the {@i D&D Starter Set}.

entries.name: Port Llast
entries: This coastal town has been, at various points in its violent history, plundered by pirates, enslaved by evil cults, set ablaze, overrun by sahuagin, and raided by drow, yet it has weathered every storm and shows glimmers of renewed prosperity once more. It's the only port between Luskan and Neverwinter, and the only place between the two cities where tall cliffs give way to sandy shores. Port Llast's harbour is strewn with shipwrecks; the tombs of seafarers who fought for the town's spoils and lost.

Although pirate attacks along the coast have spelled doom for many coastal towns, Port Llast is flourishing. The town's First Captain, Helvig Brightwood (LN female Illuskan human {@creature noble} with a {@item +3 longsword}), has made a deal with the Ships of Luskan. In return for Port Llast's protection Luskan is paid a cut of the harbour tax which the town collects from anchoring ships (2 gp a day). Because of this, the harbour of Port Llast is guarded at all times by two Luskar {@item galleon|CallfromtheDeep|galleons} crewed by thirty {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} each. The harbour is fortified by a sea wall, atop which are two {@object mangonel|dmg|mangonels} (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). Overseeing the defences and influencing the First Captain is Anther Stoneharrow (N male Illuskan human {@creature veteran}) who works for Ship Kurth.

Floating in the harbour is a massive {@item bireme|CallfromtheDeep} called The Bookwyrm painted with white and yellow stripes. The boat sits low in the water bobbing rhythmically with the waves, and is often a hub of activity. Many of the folk of Port Llast visit the ship, travelling out to it on smaller rowboats and returning with elaborately carved wooden boxes.

Characters inquiring about the boat are told it is a travelling library that moves up and down the Sword Coast swapping and loaning books. The library is run by the Order of the First Scribe, a community of monks devoted to Deneir (sixteen {@creature acolyte|mm|acolytes} of {@deity Deneir|Faerûnian|scag} of mixed races and genders). It is led by Sam Silvereyes (NG non-binary lightfoot halfling {@creature priest}), a kind-hearted halfling who sings the praises of Deneir and promotes literacy across the Realms. The library disperses free copies of the Tome of Universal Harmony, a seminal text of Deneir, and loans out rarer books for 5 sp a day, with a deposit of 25 gp. The rarer books are given out in enchanted boxes which are watertight and float. The Bookwyrm is due to leave Port Llast tomorrow afternoon, headed south for Neverwinter.

Sam Silvereyes doesn't know that their partner, Jasper Littlefellow (see below), has fallen into the clutches of the Kraken Society. Promised with greater knowledge, Jasper weakened to the telepathic communications which he assumes come from an aspect of Deneir. Jasper is currently on his way back from Luskan, where he and fellow Krakenar agents stole a {@item tome of the deep|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) from the Hosttower of the Arcane. As soon as they arrive the following morning The Bookwyrm leaves for Neverwinter. Sam is loyal to Jasper, defending him even if the theft is revealed.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The morning after the characters arrive The Bookwyrm prepares to leave. A small {@item cog|CallfromtheDeep} cuts through the waves toward the boat. The smaller vessel drops anchor close to The Bookwyrm and its crew use {@item grappling hook|phb|grappling hooks} to swing aboard. The crew consists of four {@creature martial arts adept|vgm|martial arts adepts} and {@creature Jasper Littlefellow|CallfromtheDeep} (N male lightfoot halfling), who uses the statistics of a {@creature martial arts adept|vgm} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: Jasper's size is Small.
His speed is 25 feet.
When he rolls a 1 on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, he can reroll the die and must use the new roll.
He has advantage on saving throws against being frightened.
He can move through the space of any creature that is a size larger than his.
He can attempt to {@action hide} even when he is obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than him.

He wields a {@item staff of thunder and lightning} ({@hit 4} to hit). As an action, he can make two attacks with the staff, which deals 5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if used with two hands, on a hit.

entries: After the crew from the {@item cog|CallfromtheDeep} board, The Bookwyrm leaves port. Before disppearing from sight, however, four {@creature drow} fighters and four {@creature drow spy|oota|drow spies} led by Braelin Janquay (LN male {@creature drow elite warrior} with a {@item helm of teleportation}) teleport onto the ship. The drow fight with Jasper and his allies. After the first round of combat, Sam runs onto the deck and joins the fight on Jasper's side. The drow are agents of Bregan D'aerthe, a society of male drow run by Jarlaxle who keep Luskan in check. Jarlaxle himself sent the drow after Jasper to recover the stolen {@item tome of the deep|CallfromtheDeep}.

If the characters do nothing to intervene Jasper uses his staff to devastating effect, killing several of the drow and severely injuring Braelin, who teleports himself and the remaining Bregan D'aerthe drow back to Luskan.

entries.name: Purple Rocks
entries: This cluster of rocky islands far to the west in the Trackless Sea is named for the dark purple hue that they take under stormy skies. The two largest islands among the Purple Rocks have one settlement apiece: the town of Vilkstead on the Utheraal and the slightly smaller town called Ulf of Thuger on Trisk. Each island also has its own king: SeaKing Frannis of Utheraal and Sea-King Krulk of Trisk (CN male Illuskan human {@creature gladiator|mm|gladiators}).

The Norls of Utheraal and Trisk are under the sway of the kraken Slarkrethel. They show their devotion, among other ways, by tossing their newborn children into the sea. The islanders have tattoos of krakens made of squid ink and build {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|longships} that boast kraken-shaped figureheads. They greet visitors with food and shelter but don't speak of Slarkrethel or the absence of children to outsiders.

Purple Rocks is home to the highest-ranking members of the Kraken Society (see "{@adventure Pirate Kings & Kraken Priests|CallfromtheDeep|8}" for information on uncovering this location, and "{@adventure Purple Rocks|CallfromtheDeep|8|Purple Rocks}" in chapter 4 for a full description).

entries.name: Red Larch
entries: Named for a distinctive stand of red larch trees that were cut down when the village was founded, Red Larch is situated on a fertile patch of land on the western outskirts of the Sumber Hills, where the Kheldell Path and the Cairn Road meet the Long Road. Despite its small size Red Larch offers many amenities, including the Allfaiths Shrine, a place of worship that caters to multiple faiths; the Swinging Sword, a respectable three-story inn with a high-pitched roof; and the Helm at Highsun, a ramshackle, lively tavern.
A map of Red Larch and a detailed description of the village and its inhabitants can be found in the adventure {@adventure Princes of the Apocalypse|PotA|1|Red Larch Locations}.

entries.name: Red Rocks
entries: Off the coast lies a collection of tiny islets known collectively as Red Rocks. Most of these landforms are sea stacks carved by the waves of the Sea of Swords, but some are little more than boulders peeking above the waves. Red Rocks has sunk countless ships over the centuries, so sailors tend to give them a wide berth. Fishers in smaller vessels frequent these waters though, as the area is home to many shellfish, several of which are prized in Waterdeep.

Characters who sail through the rocks in a ship that requires more than two crew members run the risk of scuppering their ship. The crew must succeed on a DC 16 group Dexterity check. Failure causes the ship smashing against the rocks, taking 27 ({@damage 5d10}) bludgeoning damage.

Characters navigating through the Red Rocks encounter a group of merfolk who live in sea caves beneath the rocky sea stacks. The merfolk here are more aggressive than other communities of their kind and collect tolls from ships that pass by. A normal {@creature merfolk tribal warrior|CallfromtheDeep|citizen of Red Rocks} uses the statistics of a {@creature tribal warrior} with the following changes:

items: A member of the Red Rocks merfolk community is lawful evil.
They have AC 14 ({@item hide armor|phb|hide armour}, {@item shield|phb}).
Their speed is 10 ft., and they have a 40 ft. swim speed.
They have proficiency in {@skill Perception} ({@d20 2|+2|Perception}).
They can speak {@language primordial|phb|Aquan} and {@language Common}.
They can breathe air and water.

entries: The reason for the aggressive nature of the merfolk has been speculated about by sailors for perhaps hundreds of years, but few know the truth. Red Rocks was once a kraken hatchery, where the monolithic beasts stored their eggs. The local merfolk were corrupted by the evil influence of the leviathans and were forced to serve as guards and caretakers for the newly born krakens. Although no eggs have been left here for centuries, the merfolk still pledge allegiance to the krakens, specifically to Slarkrethel.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Vessels that travel through Red Rocks are spied upon by the merfolk. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher notice their shadowed forms lurking in the shadows. Unless characters are hitching a ride in an unremarkable fishing ship, the merfolk watch them for a while and then head back into the depths of Red Rocks.

Within an hour, the characters' ship is attacked by a {@creature giant shark} dominated by {@creature Tempest|CallfromtheDeep} (NE male merfolk {@creature warlock of the great old one|vgm} wielding a {@item +2 rod of the pact keeper}). On initiative 10 the following round Tempest and five {@creature merfolk tribal warrior|CallfromtheDeep|merfolk tribal warriors} (see above) join combat. The merfolk aim to damage the ship before asking for a payment of 1,000 gp lest they sink it. If the shark is killed, or Tempest drops to half his hit points or less, the merfolk flee.

Unlike many members of the Kraken Society, the merfolk of Red Rocks know the faction is run by Slarkrethel. They don't know about the incursion of the illithids though. Characters who capture and interrogate a merfolk can get this information from them with a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check. Characters sneaking into the underwater caves in the sea stacks might also gather clues about this information, as each contains cave art of kraken, their eggs, and their merfolk defenders.

entries.name: Reghed Glacier
entries: The cold winds that give Icewind Dale its name blow down off this high, frozen landscape. Few dare to venture near the high walls of its easternmost edge, and little is known of what might live on or within the glacier.

entries.name: Roaringshore
entries: This isolated village is nestled in a small, deep-water cove on the coast about a third of the way south from the mouth of the Winding Water toward the city of Baldur's Gate. Unlike Lathtarl's Lantern to the north, Roaringshore remains a notorious pirate hold, the reputation of which has spread far along length of the Sword Coast. Roaringshore is a dangerous place to be for normal folk, as the hold is filled with runaways, thieves, and the most ruthless of pirates, many of whom crew ships loyal to Sea King Tentrix.

Roaringshore has no official leader, the closest is Harrick Ironguard (NE male Tethyrian human {@creature swashbuckler|vgm}), a Krakenar who runs the Broken Goblet: a disreputable tavern adored by pirates throughout the Sea of Swords. Many folk join the Kraken Society through this place, turning their crimes into collections for the faction's coffers, though none know the truth behind the society.

The Broken Goblet is famed for its ornate, lewd drinking glasses which are hand blown in the village. It is also warded against spellcasters, shrouding any without a '{@item ward token|CallfromtheDeep}' in an {@spell antimagic field}. Despite this, there are charms on the tavern itself, the most notable being the altered {@spell reverse gravity} spell which draws all thrown projectiles to the ceiling, and {@spell continual flame} spells which light the place.

The Broken Goblet is home to a rogue {@creature mind flayer} named G'zagrix. Most of the staff are its thralls, though it maintains an alliance with Harrick based on free staff labour for him, and brains for G'zagrix. The antimagic suffused throughout the tavern has no effect of the illithid's psionic abilities. G'zagrix despises other illithid, especially those loyal to elder brains and, should the characters accept the brain-eating monster as an ally, could provide insights into the Colony of Zellix'Phor and its attendants.

entries.name: Ruathym
entries: The barbarians of Ruathym, the ancestral home of the Northlanders, are at war with Luskan and have been for as long as any of them can remember. Luskanite raiders have plundered and razed the island's settlements many times, but the natives keep rebuilding their villages and ships while singing songs of bloody vengeance.

The reigning king of Ruathym is First Axe Vok Dorrg (CE male Illuskan human {@creature priest}), a blind and vindictive old man who worships {@deity Valkur|Faerûnian|scag}, a lesser god of the sea. The king rules from the Hall of Black Waves, a temple in the seaside town of Ruathym. Though he's too old to take up arms himself, Vok Dorrg has many fierce sons and grandsons to captain his ships and terrorise his enemies.

The Ruathen were once betrayed by agents of the Kraken Society who tried to rekindle the war between Ruathym and Luskan by pickling elves in casks and stowing them on Ruathen boats. Ever since, the Northmen of the isle have been on the lookout for Krakenar who they execute if found. Ruathym can provide a safe harbour for characters fleeing the society, as only the most powerful members of the Krakenar would dare step foot on Ruathym. The island also houses a great library called the Green Rooms which is filled with arcane lore. Characters openly investigating the Kraken Society are given access to the library by First Axe Dorgg, who does all he can to help them in their search.

Ever worried about the view of Luskan in the eyes of the Lords' Alliance, Jarlaxle Baenre has sent three members of Bregan D'aerthe, disguised as Northlanders, to Ruathym to keep eyes on the court of First Axe Dorgg and ensure that tempers don't boil over again and bring war to Luskan. Both states are constantly raiding each other's ships, which is mostly tolerated, but Jarlaxle worries that when First Axe Dorgg dies his successor might not be so understanding.

Characters might notice the three agents meeting in the Green Rooms each afternoon. If a character observes one of these meetings and succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, they notice that the Norls speak with an Elvish accent and exchange hand signals when they think no one is looking. A drow character recognises the signals as {@language Drow Sign Language|CallfromtheDeep}. Additionally, the disguises don't stand up to physical inspection, meaning characters who interact with the three have a chance to notice the illusion.

The drow agents are Zarquin Do'Arren, {@creature Clezzt Marcre|CallfromtheDeep} and {@creature Azaki Caphaxath|CallfromtheDeep} (LN males) and use the statistics of {@creature drow elite warrior|mm|drow elite warriors} with the following {@footnote additional features|Included in the linked statblocks.} that increase their challenge rating to 6 (2,300 XP):

items.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the drow can use a bonus action to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} action.

items.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The drow deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the drow that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the drow doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Each drow wears a {@item token of disguise|CallfromtheDeep} (an iron amulet embossed with a spider emblem that functions as a {@item hat of disguise}).

Although the other drow don't yet know it, Zarquin Do'Arren has been replaced by a {@creature doppelganger} named Yhog hired by the Kraken Society. Thanks to the inquisition-style tactics of the Ruathen against Krakenar agents, using a doppelganger seemed the only way to infiltrate the island. The Krakenar don't know that Yhog accidentally targeted a member of Bregan D'aerthe instead of a Ruathen, but Yhog relishes the opportunity to interact with so many factions. Yhog ambushed Zarquin and drowned him off Ruathym's north coast. The doppelganer doesn't know that a recent cold snap froze the ocean around the island and the drow's body has been found encased in ice.

If characters investigate the Kraken Society in the Green Rooms, the doppelganger approaches them disguised as a Northlander called Uin and attempts to form a friendship. The doppelganger is a master deceiver and knows enough about the Krakenar to keep characters interested. If it thinks the characters have uncovered too much and are a threat, it tries to assassinate them one by one.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: A few days after the characters first arrive in Ruathym there is uproar in the marketplace of the coastal town. Standing pride of place in the square is a 6-foot tall, 3-foot wide and deep block of ice containing the frozen corpse of the drow Zarquin. The islanders have no idea what the corpse is doing on Ruathym and paranoia abounds. Many of the Ruathen are panicked and have started to form a levvy of armed {@creature berserker|mm|bersekers} and {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} ready to search the island from top to bottom for drow invaders.

At the same time, the disguised {@creature Clezzt Marcre|CallfromtheDeep|Clezzt} and {@creature Azaki Caphaxath|CallfromtheDeep|Azaki} (posing as Northmen Clet and Azak) are frantically trying to get off the island, which the characters might be able to assist. They don't know how Zarquin came to be frozen in ice, but it's only so long before he thaws, and the locals discover his {@item token of disguise|CallfromtheDeep}. Since the three arrived on the island together, that would place them under suspicion.

Meanwhile, the {@creature doppelganger} has chosen a new Northlander form, that of a woman named Igrith, to avoid detection. Characters might wonder where their new friend Uin has gone and put two and two together.

entries.name: Sea of Moving Ice
entries: The sea west of Icewind Dale is a maze of shifting ice sheets and icebergs. A few frozen islands are inhabited by tribes of Ice Hunters, a group of humans the Northlanders pushed toward the pole long ago. It's not uncommon to see a frost giant greatship traverse these waters hunting whales, walruses, and seals.

The Sea of Moving Ice the domain of several white dragons, the largest and most powerful of which are the {@creature ancient white dragon|mm|ancient white dragons} Arauthator and Arveiaturace. Each dragon makes its lair inside a hollowed-out iceberg. Arauthator's iceberg, Oyaviggaton, has Northfolk barbarians living on it and is described in the adventure {@adventure The Rise of Tiamat|RoT|2|Oyaviggaton}. Arveiaturace is known to hunt in Icewind Dale and the nearby settlements of Ironmaster and Fireshear.
Characters who explore the Sea of Moving Ice in wintertime are subject to {@hazard extreme cold} temperatures (see the "Wilderness Survival" section in chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Sea of Swords
entries: The sea west of the Sword Coast is known as the Sea of Swords. The islands that dot it are well mapped, as are the shipping routes and trade winds that allow access up and down the coast. Of late, the sea has been plagued by an piracy that threatens the balance of cities on the mainland and the Island Kingdoms in the ocean beyond.

entries.name: Sea Tower of Irphong
entries: Jutting from a rocky island called Irphong is a stone tower, one of several strange structures dotted around the Nelanthers. Many have speculated on the purpose of these towers, and why lights have recently appeared at their tops, but few know the truth. Rumours abound in the Nelanthers of requests for pirates and slavers to bring children no more than one month old to the Sea Tower of Irphong, where they are rewarded greatly for their squealing cargo. Pirates who have fulfilled this trade can be found in {@area Ioma Town|ioma|x} and the {@area Port of Skaug|skaug|x}, though not all are willing to admit it.

The truth is, the Sea Tower of Irphong is occupied by Tulkhan, a Red Wizard of Thay who fled to the Nelanthers after the Thayan operations in Daggerford failed. Since arriving, he has hired pirate crews to kidnap babies from the mainland, which he used in a dark ritual to reanimate the dragon turtle known as the Curse of Irphong. After a few Black Armada vessels were sunk in Asavir's Channel by the beast, Sea King Tentrix contacted Tulkhan and asked whether he'd work for the Black Armada by getting the dragon turtle to sink Lords' Alliance warships and merchant vessels passing through the Nelanthers. In return, Tentrix ensures that word doesn't reach Daggerford about the Red Wizard's location.

A ship called Day's End is docked here for most of the day and night, leaving only to pick up stranded crew from sunken ships in Asavir's Channel. Occasionally the dragon turtle comes to the Sea Tower to return magic items it has recovered from the wrecks to its master.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters whose ship is sunk by the Curse of Irphong (see the "{@area Asavir's Channel|asavirs channel|x}" section) or who are searching for the crew of the Bobbing Barrel for Mother Claws (see the "{@area Orlumbor|orlumbor|x}" section) might find themselves at the Sea Tower of Irphong. Although the entrance is always open, Tulkhan has warded the tower against intruders through the use of trapped portals, and with undead guards.

entries.title: Sea Tower of Irphong. 1 square = 5 feet

entries: {@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Sea Tower of Irphong (Player).png}.}

entries.name: S1. Tower Entrance

entries: The bleak sea tower ahead has no door in the archway which provides entry to the place. Neither are there any windows piercing the tower, leaving its exterior entirely featureless. Floating around the top are several bright balls of light which phase from green to orange and back as they drift.
Als er tekens binnenkomen, lees of parafraseer dan het volgende:
The lowest level of the tower is as featureless as its exterior save for three stone portals of red, smoke-like magic.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The lights atop of the tower are three {@creature will-o'-wisp|mm|will-o'-wisps}. The wisps sense when someone falls to 0 hit points in the tower and turn {@condition invisible}, descend through the building, and use Life Drain on the creature.

entries.name: Portal
entries: There are two portals in this room that are identical at first glance—stone rings covered in arcane glyphs. The north portal leads to {@area s2|st2}. The west portal leads to {@area s5|st5}. The rough area to which a portal would teleport a character can be determined with a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check, or by casting {@spell detect magic}. Undead creatures cannot pass through the portals.
This pitch-black room is filled with a charnel reek. Bones litter the floor. Slowly, the room fills with the noise of clacking and scraping as something shifts the skeletal remains.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When a creature appears in the area, five {@creature skeletal swarm|GoS|skeletal swarms} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) animate and attack them.

entries.name: Animating Crystal
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notice a fist-sized ruby hanging from the ceiling by an iron chain. The ruby is suspended at a height of 30 feet in this 40-foot-tall chamber. Casting {@spell detect magic} on the ruby reveals an aura of necromancy. Destroying the ruby (AC 13, 10 hit points, resistance to all damage types) or casting {@spell dispel magic} on it prevents the swarms from animating and destroys any current swarms. The sapphire is worth 25,000 gp if cleansed of necromancy magic.

entries.name: Portal
entries: The portal in this room leads to {@area s1|st1}.

Ahead is a well-stocked library. The shelves in the chamber are made of sculpted whalebone and laden with tomes and scrolls. Toward the rear of the room is a six-foot-tall iron cupboard. There are four portals in the room.

entries.name: Bookshelves
entries: There are dozens of books on the shelves in this room, each worth 25 gp and weighing 5 lbs. Any creature other than Tulkhan who takes a book from a shelf must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or be aged {@dice 1d10} years. Casting {@spell detect magic} on the shelves reveals an aura of necromancy magic, which can be removed with the {@spell dispel magic} spell.

entries.name: Wardrobe
entries: The iron wardrobe is locked. Tulkhan has the key. The wardrobe is protected with an {@spell arcane lock} but can be opened with a successful DC 30 Strength check, or a successful DC 25 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. The first creature to open the wardrobe without using the key releases three {@creature shadow|mm|shadows} into the room that immediately attack the opener. Inside the wardrobe is Tulkhan's spellbook which contains the spells he has prepared (see {@creature necromancer|vgm} statblock), ten vials of blood which act as {@item potion of longevity|dmg|potions of longevity}, and five fine red robes which are recognisable as those of a Red Wizard (30 gp each).

entries.name: Portals
entries: The north portal leads to {@area s1|st1}. The south portal leads to {@area s4|st4}. The west portal leads to {@area s2|st2}. A creature that steps through the east portal must make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) necrotic damage and is {@disease Tulkhan's Curse|CallfromtheDeep|cursed}. On a successful save, the creature takes half the damage and isn't cursed.

A cursed creature's senses slowly become dulled. At the end of each long rest, the creature takes a −1 penalty to Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and their passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score. If this penalty reaches −5, they are permanently {@condition blinded} and {@condition deafened}, and cannot taste or smell, causing them to automatically fail all Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 0.
Before the penalty reaches −5, a {@spell remove curse} spell ends the effects on a creature. After the penalty reaches −5, only a {@spell wish} spell can restore the character's senses.

A patchwork mess of children's bodies fills most of this workshop. The hideous golem's tiny arms flail wildly with even the slightest of movements as it scuttles across the room on dozens of feet. Working at a bench is a red-robed, bald man whose head is covered with black tattoos.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Tulkhan|CallfromtheDeep} (NE male Thayan human {@creature necromancer|vgm} wearing a {@item cloak of protection}) is working at the bench stitching together pieces of flesh. Bringing him tools and reagents is a {@creature tulkhan's flesh golem|CallfromtheDeep|flesh golem} (who can make five Fist attacks as an action: {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage on a hit).

Tulkhan would rather surrender than die. He has little loyalty to Sea King Tentrix and freely gives away the locations of Driftwood Docks in return for his life. He offers the characters a faithful {@item Tulkhan's map|CallfromtheDeep|map} of the Nelanthers which gives them advantage on checks made to navigate and avoid hazards while in a ship near the islands.

entries.name: Portals
entries: There are three portals in the room. The north portal leads to {@area s1|st1}, the southeast portal leads to {@area s5|st5}. The southwest portal leads to {@area s2|st2}.

A large four-poster bed bordered by red velvet curtains takes up most of this level of the tower. Spread around the room are several pieces of fine furniture decked with glassware and delicate metallic instruments. Although the room smells musty and damp, it's warm enough to be comfortable.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Hiding behind the curtains of the bed is a {@creature ghast}. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 13 or higher hear a creaking from within the bed. Other characters are surprised when the undead launches itself through the curtains toward them.

entries.name: Treasure
