entries: The assorted laboratory equipment in this room is worth 250 gp. In the unlocked drawer of a side-table next to the bed is 348 gp, 483 sp, and 12 cp, an ivory mask (150 gp), and a {@item spell scroll (6th level)|dmg|spell scroll} of {@spell create undead}.

entries.name: Portal
entries: There are three portals in this chamber. The south portal leads to {@area s1|st1}. The east portal leads to {@area s2|st2}. The west portal leads to {@area s4|st4}.

entries.name: Secomber
entries: This town of farmers, fishers, brewers, and stonecutters is perched on three hills located near the confluence of the Unicorn Run and the Delimbiyr River. Beneath these hills lie ruins that were once part of Athalantar, a bygone kingdom. The townsfolk have turned the buried ruins into cellars, larders, and shelters.

Secomber is under the heel of the Urshani hobgoblins who dwell in the High Moor and demand tribute several times a year. Secomber has no defence against the Urshani. Its residents give the hobgoblins food, homemade ale, and ore to retain their freedom. The hobgoblins' demands have left the community impoverished. Encounters with the hobgoblins are not covered in this adventure.

entries.name: Skaug
entries: Skaug is a rough-and-tumble port that welcomes pirates of every stripe, and actively discourages those who threaten the flow of grog and coin. The lawless island is a good place to fill a ship with scurvy seadogs who value plunder over all else. Life is cheap in its alleys and ale-soaked taverns.

Characters wishing to stay in Skaug must make some effort to appear as pirates. If they arrive in a vessel that belongs to a military faction they are attacked on sight by half a dozen pirate ships (see early warning system below). If they arrive in a merchant ship or known pirate ship they can get to the docks. Once in the Port of Skaug, they must attempt to blend in with the locals lest they are kicked out of town, or worse. A successful DC 13 group Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check (made with advantage if disguises are employed) is enough to keep under the radar.

Of all the infamous taverns along the wharf, the Keelhaul is the longest-running concern. Cards, dice, companions-of-the-hour, illicit substances, and questionable deals can readily be found within its creaking timbers. Drunken patrons sometimes fling newcomers and alleged cheaters down a barnacle-filled chute, ejecting them from the prow-fronted building and into the cold waters of the harbour outside. A creature shoved down the chute takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) slashing damage and 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage.

The Keelhaul is run by Cleft (NE male {@creature minotaur}), so named because of the axe-scar that runs down his snout and splits his top lip. Cleft served Sea King Tentrix and still has strong ties to the captain. If he overhears adventurers asking questions about Tentrix, he sends word to the Sea King, preparing him for their arrival.

Although Skaug has no ruler, the main authority is Portmaster Celine Maliceprow (NE female Tethyrian human {@creature assassin}). She is great-granddaughter of the notorious, hook-handed Burlor Maliceprow. Maliceprow delights Skaug's debauchery and thwarts the mainland nations who try to invade the islands at every turn.

The advance warning system of Skaug plays a huge part in its defence; a series of lookout spots on the Crow's Nest Cliffs. Each contains a magical horn which, when blown, sounds a larger horn in the centre of the Port of Skaug. Different sequences of blasts indicate the presence of friend or foe, allowing locals to respond hours before ships arrive.

Although Maliceprow gets on with most of Skaug's inhabitants, she despises Sea King Tentrix. His actions have allowed pirates greater freedom lately, making her safe haven less desirable. If the characters are looking for Tentrix, Maliceprow reveals his location in Driftwood Docks and offers to repair, arm, or crew their ship if they have one. If not, she escorts the characters to the harbour, searches out a {@item caravel|CallfromtheDeep} called {@item Angel's Bane|CallfromtheDeep} and orders the captain onto the dock. She sticks her poisoned blade into his stomach, killing him in a matter of seconds. The crew cheer and she gives the vessel to the characters. The caravel has a crew of eight {@creature lizardfolk}, two {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} and five human {@creature thug|mm|thugs}, it is armed with {@object side-shears|CallfromtheDeep} and two {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: A day or two after the characters arrive in town there is a pirate wedding. As most pirates are wanted for crimes on the mainland, Maliceprow performs a special ceremony for those who wish to make their relationship 'official'. A collection box is passed around the Keelhaul for a few days before the wedding to raise funds for the event.

On the day of the wedding, a throng of people gather on the dock. At the end of the a jetty is Portmaster Maliceprow and the couple; Balama Marivaldi (NE female Turami human {@creature berserker}) and {@creature Mishann Prexijandilin|CallfromtheDeep} (LN female blue dragonborn {@creature swashbuckler|vgm}). The crowd includes {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep} (a {@creature green slaad} Pirate Lord), Cleft the {@creature minotaur} owner of the Keelhaul, {@creature Captain Callous - Chapter Three|CallfromtheDeep|Captain Callous} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), and any other pirate captain who has become notorious in your game.

As the ceremony progresses, Maliceprow takes the couple's hands and binds them together with rope. Both kneel, and Maliceprow dunks their heads into the ocean, claiming their love shall be as the sea; fearsome, deep, and everlasting. After the ceremony the donations from the Keelhaul sponsor a banquet. Folding tables are erected along the piers and steaming plates of roasted fish, seafood platters, and brightly coloured fruits are passed down, as well as dozens of bottles of wine and rum. During the meal, Sea King Tentrix stands up on one of the tables and makes a toast to the brides. He tells an embarrassing story about Mishann who served on his ship involving a dried monkey skin, too much rum, and a lot of vomit which is met with raucous laughter from all. He then gifts the brides with a pair of mithril rings before sitting back down to his meal.

Attacking Tentrix while the wedding is in full flow is a death sentence. Half the pirates in port are loyal to him, and he is escorted everywhere by Captain Scummer and four {@creature thug} bodyguards. Characters who succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check can eavesdrop on Tentrix's conversations. He details the reasons for the attacks on the Sword Coast, revealing that he was put up to it by the elders from his home; Purple Rocks. Characters might manage to follow Tentrix back to Driftwood Docks by stowing away on the {@item coaster|CallfromtheDeep} that brought him here, or by following him in a small ship or in the water.

entries.name: Small Teeth
entries: Rolling foothills give way to snow-capped, lightly-forested mountains known as Small Teeth to the north of Murann. The Teeths' winding trails often mislead travellers, and they conceal greater dangers. Local goblins, ogres, and other humanoids have grown to enormous numbers under the leadership of two strategy-conscious oni with minds for empire building. Humanoids here have learned much from their battles with humans and are hard to defeat.

entries.name: Snowdown
entries: The little isle of Snowdown, south of Alaron in the Moonshae Isles, is a possession of Amn, where Lady Erliza (LN female Tethyrian human {@creature noble}) rules from Caer Westphal. She is the second of her name, noted for her striking resemblance to her great-grandmother, the first Amnian ruler of the isle.

Since taking possession of the place, Snowdown's occupiers have felled its woods, stripped its mines, and choked its waterways with refuse. Lady Erliza and her soldiers have ruthlessly put down several rebellions, and the Ffolk here refer to her as "Bloody Erliza". Some Amnians believe the isle is becoming more trouble to hold on to than its diminishing exports are worth, and further uprisings are almost certainly brewing amongst the Ffolk, quietly supported by Alaron.

entries.name: Spine of the World
entries: Mountains of ice and black rock form a sky-scraping wall of frigid peaks across the far north, which few creatures have the ability to surmount. Brutally cold winds, avalanches, and icy rifts are the least of a traveller's problems in the Spine of the World. Tribes of giants, goblinoids, and orcs dwell there, holding every cavern or abandoned dwarven delve but those claimed by dragons.

entries.name: Star Mounts
entries: Cloaked in clouds and vaguely menacing, these mountains rise from the heart of the High Forest and are tall enough to be seen from any of its edges. The Star Mounts are the site of strange, gleaming lights on clear nights, and dragons are often seen flying to and from the peaks. Fierce winds swirl around the mountains, forcing flying creatures away or causing them to veer suddenly and crash against the rocks.

entries.name: Svardborg
entries: Svardborg is an enormous iceberg floating in the {@area Sea of Moving Ice|sea of moving ice|x} that once belonged to Jarl Storvald (see {@adventure Storm King's Thunder|skt|8}). The place consists of a few lodges perched on 50-foot-high cliffs that descend to the sea. The only access to the iceberg is a wooden pier made by the eight {@creature frost giant|mm|frost giants} that live there.

Without a ruler to guide them, the frost giants have turned to worshipping the kraken Slarkrethel, hoping that the King of the Trackless Depths might give them power in the North and break of the Ordning. If the characters haven't already been to Ironmaster, the giants leave on their raid while the characters are in Svardborg (see the "{@area Ironmaster|ironmaster|x}" section).

entries.name: Sword Mountains
entries: The steep, craggy mountains north of Waterdeep are home to a few scattered tribes of orcs and goblinoids. The hills around the Sword Mountains are strewn with the ruins of bygone kingdoms and more than a few half-forgotten dungeons and tombs.

entries.name: Thornhold
entries: Thornhold is a coastal fortress; a castle of grey stone with a thick, curved wall and two-towered central keep on the southern tip of the Mere of Dead Men. The cliff facing the sea is so sheer that no wall need be built to prevent intruders. The castle is without adornment; only crenellations and arrow slits break its solid stone face. Inside the walls, surrounding the bailey, are wooden and plaster buildings that house animals and are used for smithwork, candlemaking, gemcutting, repairing wooden items (including wagons and the like), and brewing beer.

Thornhold has been owned by the Margasters of Waterdeep, the Knights of Samular, and the Zhentarim, though is currently occupied by shield dwarves of the Stoneshaft clan. They refer to the castle as Stoneshaft Hold. The Stoneshaft dwarves are reclusive and secretive, and suspect the Margaster family of Waterdeep is plotting to attack the fortress and reclaim its ancestral holding.

Travellers are free to visit Thornhold, up to a point. The dwarves allow caravans to make camp within their walls, but forbid access to the keep and extensive caves below. Thornhold is rumoured to contain a passage to the Underdark, a claim the dwarves neither confirm nor deny.

The city is ruled by Lord Clanmaster Dworic Stoneshaft (LN male shield dwarf {@creature noble}) who is eager to hear news of Waterdeep, including the machinations of factions within, the trends of the Waterdhavian upper classes, and the recent pirate attack. Dworic is a great conversationalist and could talk for hours about the changing fashions of cities along the Sword Coast.

The city is protected by an elite armed guard called the Stonewardens. A {@creature stonewarden|CallfromtheDeep|typical member} is a {@creature knight}, with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: A member of the Stonewardens has AC 20 ({@item plate armor|phb|plate}, {@item shield|phb}), 60 ({@dice 8d8 + 24}) hit points, and a speed of 25 feet.
Zij hebben een Constitution score van 16 ({@d20 3}) en {@sense darkvision} tot een bereik van 60 voet.
Ze spreken {@language Common} en {@language Dwarvish}.
Ze hebben voordeel bij het redden van worpen tegen gif en weerstand tegen gifschade.
They wield a {@item morningstar|phb} instead of a {@item greatsword|phb} ({@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage on a hit).

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: If characters spend a night in Thornhold, their rooms are broken into by two angry {@creature stonewarden|CallfromtheDeep|Stonewardens} per character and the characters are imprisoned by them in the jail beneath the city. The following morning, an upset Lord Clanmaster visits the characters. He asks why they, his honoured guests, would feign friendship to steal from him. He accuses the characters of stealing an heirloom; a {@item mace of smiting} passed down through Clan Stoneshaft for generations.

Characters can plead their innocence with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, made with advantage if the characters have a decent alibi. On a success, Dworic apologises for the false accusation and asks the characters if they can help him track down the missing heirloom. If the check fails, the characters are imprisoned until they reveal what they did with the heirloom. Dworic believes they must have passed it onto a Margaster agent from Waterdeep. Dworic has sent a mounted force of Stonewardens to the city to demand they return the item, an act which could spark war between Waterdeep and Thornhold. The journey is around 140 miles, which the dwarves cover in five days. Characters must act before then to prevent war. Characters should have the opportunity to escape from the prison cells during guard changes, by casting spells, picking locks, and the like. Their escape attempts are made at your discretion.

Characters who investigate the crime scene are led to a vaulted hall filled with treasures. Levitating atop marble plinths are drinking horns made of emerald, exquisitely crafted helms, weapons of adamantine and mithril, and incredibly detailed sculptures of dwarven gods. The largest plinth has nothing floating above it, and it is here that the characters are directed. They are told that the item went missing around midnight, during the change of the guard. Characters can discover the following clues by looking in different places:

items.name: Plinth
entries: A successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check around the base of the plinth reveals a small peice of seaweed.

items.name: Seaweed
entries: A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check allows a character to identify the seaweed as dead man's bootlaces, a plant only found on the northern Island Kingdoms of Tuern, Purple Rocks, and Gundarlun.
A successful DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check indicates that the door has not been tampered with.
items.name: Chamber Door
Chamber Windows
entries: A successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check allows a character to notice a cold breeze coming through one of the windows, which is slightly ajar. A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check on the window allows a character to discover a piece of fabric ripped off by the frame.

items.name: Fabric
entries: A successful DC 10 Intelligence check reveals that the fabric is thick wool, probably from a cloak or cape. If this check succeeds by 5 or more, the character notices a salty smell on the material.

items.name: Guards
entries: Chatting with the guards who were watching the hall before and after the theft lets the characters know that the item went missing at midnight during the change-over. It must have occurred within the space of 5 minutes. Neither guard saw anything, but they made sure the city gates were shut immediately, so the thief might be trapped in Thornhold. A successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check reveals they are telling the truth.

items.name: Travellers
entries: Asking at local inns reveals that only two other people arrived in Thornhold at the time as the characters. One was a dwarf gemstone merchant named Gunnloda Durthane (LG female shield dwarf {@creature commoner}) who is still staying at the tavern, and the other was a halfling priest of {@deity Yondalla|Halfling|mtf} whose whereabouts is unknown. The halfling stayed a night but paid using strange gold coins with a kraken on them. Conversation with Gunnloda reveals nothing.

items.name: Halfling Priest
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 25 Charisma ({@skill Investigation}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check can follow the trail of the halfling by chatting to folk who saw him or tracing tracks through the city. Reduce the DC of the check by 5 for each day spent investigating. Eventually, the characters find Finnan Undergallow (N male lightfoot halfling {@creature master thief|vgm} wearing a {@item ring of free action}) hiding in an abandoned mining warehouse. The halfling tries to escape the characters if possible. He was unable to flee the city after stealing the {@item mace of smiting} but has hidden the weapon away as insurance on his life. Finnan is a member of the Kraken Society who joined the faction after travelling to Purple Rocks. The mace is hidden in the chimney of a forge in the warehouse and can be found with a successful DC 30 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.

If the characters discover the mace before five days pass the war between Thornhold and Waterdeep is prevented, and Lord Clanmaster Dworic rewards each character witha magic item. To determine each item, roll on {@table Magic Item Table F} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}, or allow each player to choose one item from that table. If the characters don't discover the mace in time, war breaks out. The war is not covered in the scope of this adventure, but there should be serious consequences.

entries.name: Tír faoi Thoinn
entries: South of the Moonshaes is a kelp forest known as Tír faoi Thoinn, or the Land Beneath the Waves. Scattered throughout the forest are the ruins of an elven city, twinned with that of Kressilacc, that has fallen from grace in the last few centuries. After the centuries long war between the sea elves and sahuagin, the elves were eventually defeated. Many fled for Evermeet, leaving only a handful of devoted priests of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} behind who refused to leave their temple; a series of blue claystone spires dotted with aquamarines and water opals. The ancestors of those elves still guard the temple as Sea Stewards—monks who train tirelessly to understand the currents and waves of the ocean, marine ecology, and how best to kill sahuagin.

Characters who enter the kelp forest don't get far before they are approached by four sea elf {@creature martial arts adept|vgm|martial arts adepts} riding {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} who ask their business in the Land Beneath the Waves. They fear the presence of sahuagin spies, especially malenti, and don't accept visitors to their realm light-heartedly. Worshippers of Deep Sashelas and elves who allow themselves to be examined, are permitted access to the temple, called the Undersea Spires.

entries.name: Trackless Sea
entries: Spanning west from the Sea of Swords and north to the Sea of Moving Ice is the Trackless Sea, an enormous ocean that reaches Chult in the south and Maztica in the west. These waters are home to all manner of monstrosities, and are colonised in a few places by the Island Kingdoms.

entries.name: Triboar
entries: The bustling mercantile town of Triboar stands where the Long Road meets the Evermoor Way. Triboar's name originates from a traveller's tale of slaying three boars here in the same day, over four hundred winters ago. The town is built on flat, fertile land, with a few natural rises. Nearly half of the population lives outside the town on sprawling ranches and farmsteads to the north or east.

The current lord protector of Triboar is a good-natured Harper named Darathra Shendrel (LG female Chondathan human {@creature veteran}). Darathra enacts local laws (known as "the Lord's Decree"), which are enforced by the Twelve (good-aligned male and female human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities on {@creature riding horse|mm|riding horses}), a squad of a dozen mounted warriors drawn from the militia. One of these Twelve is Sir Galdowall, to whom {@adventure Shandri Dundragon|CallfromtheDeep|2|Shandri Dundragon|0} is squire.

Triboar is a market for the horses raised by nearby ranches. Blacksmiths, harness-makers, and wagon-works also flourish in town. In addition, a number of guides operate out of Triboar. They take merchants and other travellers all over the Sword Coast, typically for stiff fees.

entries.name: Troll Hills & Trollbark Forest
entries: As can be surmised from the names of these adjacent regions, the forest and low mountains are overrun with trolls of every description. This region has the closest thing to a troll nation and common language, though the empire of trolls makes the typical orc tribe look like a king's court!

The Trollbark Forest is a dark wood of twisted oaks, black ash, and scrub pines. The forest floor is tangled with underbrush, including poisonous and carnivorous plants. Low vales in the wood are filled with bogs and swamps. In short, it is the sort of place only trolls would want to live.

The Troll Hills are little better. Oaks predominate to the timberline, and their rounded peaks are topped with thick patches of razor grass. Here the trolls live in caverns that lie beneath most of the peaks. It has been said that in ancient days drow caravans moved through here at will to a hidden drow city, but when that city was overrun by trolls, the drow destroyed all access to this area from below.

In addition to the rumored drow city beneath the Troll Hills, the Troll Hills house {@area Warlock's Crypt|warlocks crypt|x}. Said to be the final resting place of Larloch, a great wizard of Netheril protected by his immortal, devoted servants, as well as a troop of trolls, it is reported to house great magics. In recent years, the trolls of the area have been engaged in a war against the undead of Warlock's Crypt, making the area doubly dangerous for travellers.

entries.name: Trollclaws
entries: A tangled landscape of rough hills along the northern edge of the Fields of the Dead, the Trollclaws are home to a great many of the regenerating, bloodthirsty beasts. Exactly what makes these hills such prime ground for trolls is unknown, but there's no doubt that they dwell here in great numbers.

Those traveling south to Baldur's Gate or north out of the Fields of the Dead typically travel through the Trollclaws. The Trollclaw Ford is the only place for leagues that wagons can safely cross the Winding Water. Important as it is, the site has been occupied by several forces over the years, as evidenced by the ruins of forts nearby. Any claimants have always fallen eventually to prolonged troll assaults.

entries.name: Tuern
entries: The merciless Northfolk of Tuern pay tribute to three adult red dragons that live inside the island's active volcanoes; a chain of black, grumbling, lava-filled cauldrons that belch smoke and ash into the sky. Five Northfolk tribes live on the island, each with its own settlement, king, and fleet of dragon-headed longships. Four of the kings recognize the fifth, High King Ossul Haarn of Uttersea (CE male Illuskan human {@creature gladiator} with 90 hit points and a {@item ring of fire resistance}), as their liege. Uttersea is the largest town on the island and has a port for the High King's {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} armada. The island is also home to small families of fire giants who strive to unseat the island's draconic overlords.

The dragons' lair is a deep crevasse in the western mountains called Flame Fault. The {@creature adult red dragon|mm|adult red dragons} are siblings called Velcuagos (male), Tchathraag (male), and Pyrozzathra (female), and are guardians of a githyanki crèche cut into the side of Flame Fault. The crèche is important not just because young githyanki are born and trained here, but because the dragon siblings have pledged themselves to the githyanki and offer their young as mounts for the githyanki knights. The staff looking after the crèche changes every few months so no githyanki is forced to age on the Material Plane for long. The current leader is Zar'ryth (LE female {@creature githyanki kith'rak|mtf}). She is aware that a nautiloid has crashed on Gundarlun and has sent her agents to track down the mind flayers, but has only got as far as Purple Rocks. She also sent agents to the Cloaktower in Neverwinter, which she falsely believes is a threat to the safety of Tu'narath, their city in the Astral Plane.

Characters who visit the githyanki with information about mind flayers are cautiously welcomed with an armed guard of eight {@creature githyanki knight|mm|githyanki knights}. They are allowed to meet Zar'ryth who provides three {@creature githyanki knight|mm|githyanki knights} and three {@creature young red dragon|mm|young red dragons} as allies should the characters wish to assault the illithids. She also deploys an astral skiff if it is useful. Characters in the company of Felenzi'ir are rewarded by Zar'ryth with a magic item. To determine each item, roll on {@table Magic Item Table F} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}, or allow each player to choose one item from that table. The githyanki have a {@creature berbalang|mtf} spy in the lair of Sea King Tentrix. They falsely believe that Tentrix is an illithid thrall.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The first time characters visit Tuern, a trio of {@creature githyanki knight|mm|githyanki knights} riding {@creature young red dragon|mm|young red dragons} flies over the coast toward Purple Rocks. The githyanki are on a mission to scout out the island in preparation for a full-scale invasion, believing the Rocklanders to be harbouring mind flayers from the crash. Seeing the dragons approach, the warriors of Uttersea frantically gather arms and man the siege weapons Uttersea has to defend itself. A few {@object ballista} bolts are fired toward the dragons and are met with blasts of fire.

Characters who talk with the warriors or High King Haarn find out that this is a common occurrence. Each time the warriors attempt to shoot the dragons, but they have not yet succeeded. Tuernish have not noticed that the dragons are ridden by githyanki, and they are oblivious of the race's presence on the island. They do know of the red dragons on the island though, and that they lair in Flame Fault.

entries.name: Tulmene
entries: The small settlement on Tulmene on the south coast of the Tethyr Peninsula would be little more than a fishing village save for its sizable shipyard and dock. Its proximity to the Nelanther makes Tulmene a dangerous place, constantly occupied by pirate crews of one ship or another. Because of this the mayor of Tulmene, a gruff old man named Jakar Pyllam IV (N male Tethyrian human {@creature thug}), has made a deal with Sea King Tentrix that ensures Tulmene won't be attacked by pirates in return for free ship repairs and a berth in the harbour. Furthermore, keen fishing crews looking to make extra coin act as informants for the pirates, letting them know when merchant vessels pass through {@area Asavir's Channel|asavirs channel|x} and The Race, an unprotected tract of water south of the Tethyrian Peninsula.

Characters asking questions about Tentrix in Tulmene are given false information and reported to Jakar who sends a {@creature spy} to watch them while they are in town. Tulmene has a few taverns, including the four-storey quality inn, Tulmene's Tower, and The Five Daggers—a dive bar frequented by visiting pirates and cutthroats. Tulmene also has a temple to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} and {@deity Valkur|Faerûnian|scag} called the Wavelord's House.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: While characters are staying in Tulmene, {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep}—a {@creature spirit naga} Pirate Lord loyal to Sea King Tentrix, arrives on a damaged {@item caravel|CallfromtheDeep} with a crew of fifteen assorted {@creature lizardfolk}, {@creature orc|mm|orcs}, and humanoid {@creature thug|mm|thugs}. They pull into Pyllam Shipyards where their vessel is repaired. Desecratus and a handful of the crew head to The Five Daggers where they stay for a few days.

You can use this as an opportunity to feed characters information about Sea King Tentrix and his floating lair in Driftwood Docks. It can also be used as a chance for characters to kill one of Tentrix's Pirate Lords before they head to Driftwood Docks, thus making the encounter there easier. However, if the Desecratus Profanis is not killed discretely, or if the mayor's {@creature spy} witnesses the event, the militia of Tulmene, a group of ten neutral-aligned male and female {@creature guard|mm|guards} of various ethnicities, are sent after the characters to bring them to justice.

entries.name: Underwave
entries: Underwave is the coral palace of Sultan Klaptikos of the Great Wave, a {@creature marid} currently trapped in a {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} (see "{@adventure Waterdeep|CallfromtheDeep|6}" in chapter 2). Despite his absence, the wardens of Underwave, triton and genasi {@creature guard|mm|guards}, ensure the palace isn't captured by the Sultan's foes or monsters of the deep. Underwave can be found to the west of the Moonshae Isles but is several thousand feet below the waves. Characters without teleportation magic or the ability to breathe water cannot hope to reach the palace. Water pressure is also an issue at this depth while not inside the palace grounds (see "{@hazard Water Pressure|CallfromtheDeep}" sidebar).

While Klaptikos is away, the Warden of Underwave is a triton called {@creature Jhimas Pumanath|CallfromtheDeep}. He eagerly awaits Klaptikos' return and ensures the palace is not infiltrated by enemies by denying entry to all visitors. Jhimas uses the statistics of a {@creature gladiator} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statistics.}:

items: Jhimas is lawful neutral.
He has an armour class of 17 ({@item +1 breastplate}, {@item shield|phb}).
He has a swim speed of 30 feet.
He can speak {@language Common} and {@language Primordial}.
He can breathe air and water.
He can communicate simple ideas with any beast that can breathe water.
He has resistance to cold damage and is acclimated to an underwater environment.
He wields a {@item trident|phb} instead of a {@item spear|phb}.
Jhamis' innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 13). Jhamis can innately cast the following spells, requiring no matierla components:
1/day each: {@spell fog cloud}, {@spell gust of wind}, {@spell wall of water|xge}

entries.name: Velen
entries: This small duchy takes a great deal of pride in its freedom. Politically, it has a reputation for conducting itself with honour, and it insists on the same high standards from its citizens and visitors. With enemies on all sides, Velen conducts most of its trade by sea in spite of constant threats by the pirates of the Nelanther Isles.

Troubles beset this small forested realm, ranging from pirates, unquiet spirits, and politics. Many ghosts haunt the city, but living residents get by well enough as long as they leave the recalcitrant spirits in peace. To the east, the ogre kingdom of Muranndin cuts Velen off from the Trade Way. The pirates of the Nelanther Isles threaten its western coasts. Powerful Amnian interests have rendered the Duke of Velen almost powerless in his own land. Tethyr is far away and spares few resources for its ally.

In response to the gathering threats, Duke Calchais (LN male Tethyrian {@creature noble}) has enforced stricter and stricter laws in recent years, though their harsh nature is concealed in rhetoric about honour and loyalty. Murderers are executed, which most accept as apt punishment, assuming the criminals are guilty. Thieves have their possessions confiscated, and must work in service of the robbed person for a period of time based on the value of the stolen item. Even being caught in a lie is cause for a whipping. Citizens have begun speaking against these draconian laws, but quietly, lest they besmirch the Duke's honour.

entries.name: Warlock's Crypt
entries: On the western edge of the Troll Hills lies an area of bizarre terrain: shattered rubble is strewn across the landscape between mounds of upturned earth and furrows of the sort one sees in the wake of trebuchet blows that miss their mark. Farther in from the perimeter of this blasted land lies a scattered mess of buildings, some relatively intact, others half-collapsed and leaning on their neighbours. In the centre, rising above it all is a handful of twisted towers looking for all the world like talons clawing at the sky. These towers can be seen from a good distance, seemingly unharmed by the cataclysm that produced the damage around them. Indeed, because of their pristine condition, folk conjecture that these towers were built after that event.

The truth of the place now called Warlock's Crypt is something different altogether. All the structures visible here, from the now-shattered outbuildings to the central towers, comprised a city that once floated atop a disc of stone during the time of ancient Netheril. When the ancient and wicked magics of the Netherese failed, the city plummeted from the sky; the chunks and slabs of stone scattered about the site are not natural terrain but are the shards of that disc. Warlock's Crypt is rife with undead under the command of a {@creature lich} dubbed the Shadow King. These creatures spill out beyond the walls of the strange city and into the surrounding Trollbark Forest and Troll Hills in search of fresh meat.

entries.name: Waterdeep
entries: Waterdeep is a prominent city on the Sword Coast. See chapter 2 "{@adventure Waterdeep|CallfromtheDeep|6}" or the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag|2|Waterdeep|0} for more information on this location.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Unless it has already happened, you can run the "{@adventure Attack on Waterdeep|CallfromtheDeep|6|Attack on Waterdeep}" encounter (see chapter 2) when the characters visit the city.

entries.name: Westbridge
entries: A village strung along the Long Road between Red Larch and Triboar, Westbridge (named because it lies to the west of the Stone Bridge) is home to the Harvest Inn. The inn's proprietor is the affable Herivin Dardragon (CG male strongheart halfling {@creature commoner}), a curly-haired collector and seller of paintings and statuettes of questionable taste.

entries.name: Westwood
entries: A tangled forest cloaking the eastern foothills of the Sword Mountains, the Westwood is home to a shrine of {@deity Mielikki|Faerûnian|scag}, several woodcutters' camps that are often taken over by bandits or Uthgardt barbarians, and a few overgrown remnants of the ancient elven kingdom of Rilithar.

entries.name: Whalebones
entries: Petty, warmongering kings rule over dozens of small islands known as the Whalebones, so called because of the whale skeletons that litter the islands' beaches. Many have made their fortunes by stealing bones from the islands, but not so many as have met their end at the hands of the locals for trying. Several of the larger islands are home to rocs that the storm giants of {@area Maelstrom|maelstrom|x} use as mounts. The islanders leave treasure and food for the giants and birds as tribute.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: While travelling past the Whalebones, two {@creature storm giant|mm|storm giants} emerge from the Trackless Sea and call down their {@creature roc} mounts. The Storm Giants are from {@area Maelstrom|maelstrom|x} and on their way to Purple Rocks, where they fear something is wrong with Slarkrethel. They don't know exactly what is wrong with the kraken, but King Hekaton believes he has been corrupted by some evil, alien force. Characters can accompany the friendly storm giants to Purple Rocks or ask to be taken to Maelstrom to talk with King Hekaton.

entries.name: Wood of Sharp Teeth
entries: The Wood of Sharp Teeth, previously the Glimmerwood, is dominated by large, moisture-loving trees such as swamp white oak, black willow, and green ash, which tower over the thick undergrowth. As its name suggests, the wood is crawling with lycanthropes, mostly werewolves, who are rumoured to be allies of a former Grand Duke of Baldur's Gate, Valarken. The edges of the forest are patrolled by Flaming Fist mercenaries who ward away travellers.

entries.name: Wreck of the Sea Witch
entries: The infamous Sea Witch sank off the western coast of {@area Ioma|ioma|x}, and many a salvager has tried to find it since. The ship was known for its complement of spell-slingers. These personnel allowed the captain, Mala Ravenstar, to employ a variety of diabolical tactics against foes. All assume the sunken ship's hold must be bursting with magic treasure.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters who dive down to the wreck find it crawling with ten {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} and a {@creature coelenite mass mind|CallfromtheDeep}. The creatures have colonised the wreck because they are inexorably drawn to the magic items within. Little more than the hold of the ship remains which is now covered by coral. If characters kill or sneak past the coelenites they can recover magic items from the wreck. Characters who succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, or who cast {@spell detect magic}, can locate {@dice 1d4} magic items from {@table Magic Item Table F} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Yartar
entries: The fortified city of Yartar stands on the east bank of the Dessarin River. On the west bank is a walled fort under the city's control. Between them stretches a stone bridge. Travellers must move through the citadel and pass inspection before continuing to Triboar or crossing the bridge to the city's west gate. The Evermoor Way cuts through the heart of Yartar, connecting the city's west and east gates. Yartar is prosperous, and becoming increasingly crowded. Many of its old buildings have been torn down and replaced by taller, built-four story accomodation.

The current Waterbaron of Yartar is Nestra Ruthiol (LE female Tethyrian human {@creature noble}), a shrewd woman in her fifties. Yartar is a member of the Lords' Alliance, and Ruthiol considers this vital to her city's prosperity. She knows that Harpers and Zhentarim are established in the city, but her path crosses with theirs only when the well-being of Yartarrans is threatened. Both factions have infiltrated the all-female thieves' guild, the Hand of Yartar.

After the machinations of Lord Khaspere Drylund were {@adventure thwarted|skt|12}, the Kraken Society have withdrawn from Yartar. Only a few Krakenar remain within the city, most of whom are lying low until they receive further communication from their superiors. The Grand Dame has been taken over by a new owner, and is no longer affiliated with the society.

entries.name: Development
entries: By completing quests presented at the end of chapter 2, and exploring locations presented in this chapter, characters should discover clues leading to the Kraken Society in Purple Rocks, and Sea King Tentrix in Driftwood Docks.

The next chapter details these locations in full and provides the missing pieces of the puzzle that send the characters to Ascarle, the lair of Slarkrethel, which has been taken over by the Colony of Zellix'Phor

entries.name: Chapter 4: Pirate Kings & Kraken Priests
entries: After completing the quests detailed in chapter 2, and exploring the Sword Coast and Island Kingdoms in chapter 3, the characters should have a good idea about who organised the attacks on the Sword Coast. The Black Armada was formed by Sea King Tentrix, a notorious pirate king. Characters should hunt down Tentrix by following clues gained in the previous chapters, which lead them to Driftwood Docks in the Nelanther Isles.

Characters might have an inclination that the Black Armada and the Kraken Society are linked. They might not fully understand the connection at this point; that Tentrix is a Kraken Priest from Purple Rocks, but their encounter with the pirate king should reveal this fact, and send them on the next stage of their journey to Purple Rocks.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: The characters should advance to at least 8th level before they assault Sea King Tentrix's Floating Fortress or Purple Rocks in chapter 4.

entries.name: Travel to the Pirate Isles
entries: By this point in the adventure, the characters should have access to a ship of their own or have formed a strong alliance with the captain of a loyal ship who can take them to the Nelanthers. Alternatively, the characters might have gained access to some form of teleportation magic or the ability to travel underwater. Any of these methods of travel should allow them to reach Driftwood Docks.

Travelling to the Nelanther Isles themselves is an easy task, as the pirate isles are detailed on almost every map of the region. Sailors and merchants know to avoid the islands and to be wary of {@area Asavir's Channel|asavirs channel|x} and The Race, the stretches of water that connect the isles to the mainland.

Characters might have a harder time finding Driftwood Docks, the lair of Sea King Tentrix, as it is only found on detailed maps of the islands. Characters might travel past the enormous ship graveyard and discover it by chance, force a pirate captain of the Black Armada to reveal the location, or pay a hefty price for a detailed map of the Nelanthers to discover its location.

entries.name: Tentrix & Pirate Lords
entries: The following section contains roleplaying information for Sea King Tentrix and the pirate lords of the Black Armada. {@note Hold <kbd>CTRL</kbd> when hovering to view an Info tab.}

items: {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} (NE male Illuskan human)
{@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep} (CN non-binary {@creature green slaad})
{@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep} (LE female {@creature spirit naga})
{@creature Dhurge|CallfromtheDeep} (LE male sahuagin baron)
{@creature Jarl Bluebeard|CallfromtheDeep} (CE male frost giant)
{@creature The Storm Maiden|CallfromtheDeep} (N female Illuskan human)

entries.name: Lesser Pirates
entries: On the top rung of the ladder is Sea King Tentrix. He commands the Black Armada, as well as his lair in Driftwood Docks. Serving directly beneath him are the pirate lords who ensure his orders are fulfilled. Beneath them are pirates of lesser import, who have specific roles.

items: {@creature Kharon|CallfromtheDeep}
{@creature Luthra 'Powder' Lingenhall|CallfromtheDeep}
{@creature Grabbit|CallfromtheDeep}

entries.name: Driftwood Docks
entries: Driftwood Docks is a ship graveyard inhabited by the nastiest pirates of the Sword Coast. The location was once little more than a handful of sharp rocks and fast currents, but as more ships foundered in the treacherous waters, their skeletons built up genuine islands. In the centre of these wooden islands is a deep harbour containing the lair of Sea King Tentrix; a dozen partially dismembered pirate vessels that are lashed together to form a floating fortress.

Driftwood Docks is constantly patrolled by pirates loyal to Tentrix. In charge of the defence of Driftwood Docks is Jarl Bluebeard, a brutal frost giant on the verge of insanity who has a habit of hurling rocks.

Characters who arrive at Driftwood Docks must navigate the treacherous waters and overcome the defences of the ship graveyard before they can enter the bay containing Tentrix's lair. Once aboard, they might capture or kill the Sea King and extract information from him or one of his pirate lords, allowing them to progress to Purple Rocks.

entries.name: Approaching Driftwood Docks
entries: When the characters first approach the island of smashed ships, read or paraphrase the following:

In the distance are the steep sides of an island formed entirely of smashed ships. The ship graveyard is surrounded by almost unnavigable waters that roil and twist as if wrung by the hands of the gods.
When characters arrive at Driftwood Docks for the first time during a day or start a day of travel there, have them make a skill challenge.

entries.name: Skill Challenge
entries: The characters must succeed on five DC 20 ability checks before failing three to safely navigate the dangerous waters surrounding Driftwood Docks. Allow any reasonable skill to be used, such as the following examples:

items: Strength check to guide the ship around rocks like a punt
Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check to stay upright on the rocking deck
Constitution check to keep a staunch grip on ropes for hours on end
Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check to decipher the chaotic pattern of currents
Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) chart a course through a reef
Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check om de bemanning te inspireren

entries: If the characters fail three checks before succeeding on five, their ship is battered by the rocks and reefs, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) bludgeoning damage. The characters still reach their destination provided that their ship isn't destroyed by this damage. If the characters succeed on five checks before failing three, they safely arrive at their destination having avoided the dangers of Driftwood Docks.
Characters might find alternative ways into Driftwood Docks, such as stowing aboard a pirate ship or teleporting. These methods have their own complications, the scope of which is not covered here.

entries.name: Driftwood Docks Entrance
entries: When characters reach the entrance to the island on its southern side, read or paraphrase the following:

The treacherous waters around the island give way to reveal a handful of gulleys which cleave through the broken ships, forming an entrance to the island's interior. The high cliffs on either side are manned by humanoids at ballistae, scouring the water for enemy ships.

The entrance to Driftwood Docks is a few hundred feet wide and consists of a handful of gullies between the cliffs. Tentrix has fortified the entrance with ballistae and drums which serve as an alarm. The defence of Driftwood Docks is the responsibility of {@creature Jarl Bluebeard|CallfromtheDeep}, who spends his time slumped against a ruined tower daydreaming.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The entrance is guarded by twenty-six {@creature thug|MM|thugs}, three {@creature ogre|MM|ogres}, and three {@creature minotaur|MM|minotaurs}. They are led by {@creature Jarl Bluebeard|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and his first mate {@creature Jandar Stayanoga|CallfromtheDeep} (NE male Rashemi human {@creature gladiator}). Each creature's behaviour is detailed in the sections below. The entrance has ten {@creature bandit} reinforcements standing by (see the "{@area Drums|dddrum|x}" section).

When characters arrive, each creature is fulfilling its duties (see below). If the characters wait, there is a changing of the guard which takes {@dice 1d4 + 1} minutes, during which time no one mans the ballistae.

entries.name: Ballistae
entries: Each large island and the bordering cliffs have {@object ballista|DMG|ballistae} (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}) bolted to their decking which are manned by four {@creature thug|MM|thugs} (mixed race and gender). The ballistae each have a barrel of nine bolts nearby, with one bolt already loaded. If the ballistae are shot at ships, one of the thugs uses their action to ignite the bolt (dealing an additional 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage on a hit). This attack ignites anything flammable it hits, including ships. If the ballistae are attacking creatures, the fourth thug uses its action to {@action Help} the shooter. Islands block line of sight.

If two or more thugs manning a ballistae die, the remaining thugs move to the closest ballistae to assist. If no ballistae can be fired effectively, the thugs flee to the border cliffs and fire their {@item heavy crossbow|phb|heavy crossbows}.

entries.name: Bridges
entries: The large islands and cliffs are connected by rickety wooden bridges just wide enough for a Large or smaller creature to travel across. Characters can move at a normal pace across the bridges, but this puts strain on their poor construction. Whenever one or more characters move at normal speed across a bridge, roll a {@dice d6}. On a roll of 1, a bridge flips, dropping characters into the water. These areas can be navigated safely by treating them as difficult terrain.

The bridges have AC 11, 18 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage, and vulnerability to fire damage. Reducing a bridge to 0 hit points destroys it, throwing any creature on the bridge into the water below.

entries.name: Cliffs
entries: The 'land' of Driftwater Docks is not stable ground; it is made of hundreds of smashed ships thrown together in ramshackle piles atop a bed of rocks. The larger 'islands' have rough decking laid down on their tops, making it easier to stand atop them. Creatures can move across the ground as normal, but a creature that takes the {@action Dash} action must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}, tripping over the debris-strewn ground.

The cliffs and islands in Driftwood Docks are 50 feet tall. A creature without an innate climbing speed can scramble up the cliffside with a successful DC 12 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Creatures can attempt to jump from high points, such as ship masts, onto the islands. See {@book chapter 8|PHB|8|Jumping} of the {@i Player's Handbook} for rules on jumping.

entries.name: Drums
entries: Each large island and the bordering cliffs have drums on their decks. These drums can be played using an action, and are manned by either an {@creature ogre} or {@creature minotaur}. If a drum is sounded, each other drummer joins in the following turn. If three or more drums are sounded simultaneously, the noise is loud enough to warn anyone in the Driftwood Docks harbour that foes are on their way (see "{@area They Saw You Coming|tsyc|x}" in the Floating Lair section). In addition, a reinforcement of ten {@creature bandit|MM|bandits} arrives on initiative 10 the following round. The bandits man {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, jump onto enemy ships, or fire their {@item light crossbow|phb|crossbows} at the crew.
Once the drums have been sounded, the drummers run to the closest cliff and jump onto invading ships.
Each drum has AC 13, 10 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Reducing a drum to 0 hit points destroys it, preventing it from being played.

entries.name: Ruined Tower
entries: To the northwest of the Driftwood Docks entrance is a ruined tower. {@creature Jarl Bluebeard|CallfromtheDeep} foolishly decided to start constructing the tower from stone atop the rough decking, but quickly realised it wouldn't hold after his own footsteps caused it to partially collapse. Now, Jarl Bluebeard uses the ruined tower as a leaning post and shark smoker. He also stores valuable possessions inside it. Within, the tower looks like a huge smokestack; a smouldering fire on the ground, with the corpse of a giant shark hanging above from a spit by its tail, slowly curing in the smoke. Stashed inside, left of the door, is the Jarl's wooden trunk, engraved with harmless giant runes.

Outside the tower is a {@item bowl of commanding water elementals} which the Jarl uses the first time enemies are detected. He sends the {@creature water elemental|mm|elemental} to attack ship captains. After that, he hurls rocks from a pile at the foes until they come into melee range, when he changes to using his {@item tentacle rod} and {@item battleaxe|phb}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: An unlocked trunk within the tower contains 1,850 gp, 4,600 sp, 230 cp, and a collection of whalebone scrimshaw (worth 500 gp). The trunk also contains a {@item potion of gaseous form}, a {@item potion of superior healing} (which the Jarl drinks if he falls below half hit points) and a {@item potion of heroism}.

entries.name: Seawater
entries: The water in Driftwood Docks is filled with ripping currents and whirlpools. Water vehicles treat the water as difficult terrain, and creatures in the water must spend 4 foot of movement for every 1 foot it moves. When a creature enters the water for the first time on a turn or starts its turn in the water, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be pulled beneath the waves. A creature already underwater who fails the saving throw takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) bludgeoning damage from being battered by debris.

entries.name: Tentrix's Floating Lair
entries: When the characters make their way through the entrance and into the harbour, read or paraphrase the following:

Up ahead is a large, deep expanse of water used as a harbour for around ten pirate ships of sundry construction. Standing out above these is a towering vessel that looks like eight ships lashed together around a central hull nearly a hundred feet across. The strange, floating structure has an enormous sail emblazoned with the sign of the Black Armada: a black skull surrounded by tentacles on a blood-red background.

entries.name: Crew
entries: The crew of Tentrix's lair is constantly rotating. Pirates who make port in Driftwood Docks serve for a tenday on the vessel before setting sail again. Because of this, the crew is a mixture of humanoids, including lizardfolk, goblins, and orcs. Like most pirates, the crew of Tentrix's lair are not particularly loyal; if outmatched, they flee.

Due to the constant changeover, it is easy for characters to blend in. Provided characters wear suitable attire ({@item traveler's clothes|phb|traveller's clothes} or a disguise) they can infiltrate the ship.
Each crew member carries {@dice 2d10} gp in a belt pouch.

entries.name: They Saw You Coming
entries: If the characters are noticed at the entrance to Driftwood Docks, or if they make their presence known aboard the lair, the crew rush to battle stations. The actions of the crew are summarised in the {@area Lair Roster Table|lairtable|x} overleaf. Characters are likely to be noticed either by the lookouts at the entrance to Driftwood Docks or by Blurg, the goblin lookout in {@area t20|t20}.

Area descriptions presented below assume the characters have not been spotted on their way to the lair, and thus life proceeds as normal for the crew. If the characters are spotted, you should adjust the descriptions to reflect the current inhabitants and their actions.

entries.name: Lair Roster Table
entries: The following roster table summarises the locations of the lair's inhabitants when the characters approach and indicates how those creatures will react when intruders are detected.

rows: Grabbit and the goblins head to {@area t2|t2}, the lizardfolk head to {@area t4|t4} to man the {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, and the bandits head to {@area t6|t6} to man the {@object cannon|dmg|cannons}.
The rug remains here until disturbed.
The lizardfolk remain here to guard the oaken bolter.
Dhurge heads out onto the deck of this area.
The bandits remain here to man the {@object cannon|dmg|cannons}.
The Storm Maiden and berserkers remain here until they see a foe to attack. The berbalang remains here and {@action Hide|phb|Hides}.
The snakes remain here until disturbed.
The minotaur remains here to man the {@object ballista}.
5 {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, 1 {@creature bard|vgm}, 2 {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}, 3 {@creature lizardfolk}, 1 {@creature minotaur}, 3 {@creature orc|mm|orcs}, 1 {@creature veteran}

The goblins head to {@area t2|t2}, the lizardfolk head to {@area t4|t4} to man the {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, the bandits head to {@area t6|t6} to man the {@object cannon|dmg|cannons}. The bard, minotaur, orcs, and veteran remain here until disturbed.

{@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep}, {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep}, {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep}, 4 {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, 1 {@creature ogre zombie}, 1 {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep}
Sea King Tentrix and Captain Scummer head to {@area t13|t13}, using the colossal octopus to block it. Desecratus and the bandits remain here.
The goblins, orcs, and bandit head to {@area t12|t12} to help defend. The monkey remains here.
All creatures remains here, though Filch follows the characters should they enter the lair.

entries.name: Locations
entries: The following sections detail the areas of Tentrix's lair:

{@note This map was made by stitching together the original, separate maps for Tentrix's Lair, which can be viewed separately {@link here|https://github.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/tree/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Tentrix Lair}. An unlabelled version of this composite map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Tentrix Lair/Collage (Player).png}.}

entries.name: General Features: Tentrix's Lair
entries: The following features are common throughout the lair:

entries.name: Balustrades
entries: Several areas, including the poop decks and mezzanine level, are bordered by low balustrades instead of walls, denoted by a dotted line. The balustrades are 4 feet high.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: The ceilings of most chambers are 8 feet high. The ceiling of {@area t12|t12} is sixteen feet high.

entries.name: Kharon
entries: The floating lair is considered the lair of {@creature Kharon|CallfromtheDeep} (see "{@footnote Lesser Pirates: Kharon|Moved to the Info tab of Kharon's bestiary entry.}"). Kharon uses their lair actions and regional effects to hinder the progress of invaders.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: All areas of the lair are well lit by oil lamps or candles suspended from the ceiling by chains, attached to pillars, or placed atop furniture.

entries.name: Noise
entries: Sounds of merrymaking and repair-work fill the ship. Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing are made with disadvantage.

entries.name: Walls
entries: The walls of the lair are made of wood (AC 15). A 10-foot square of exterior wall has 50 hit points, a 10-foot square of interior wall has 30 hit points.

In the central hub of the lair is a short goblin with a tall driftwood crown cracking a whip around her head. A pale lizardfolk backs away from her toward the edge of a wooden plank over a hole in the centre of the room.

"Scaly creeps gotta remember who da boss is!" screeches the goblin as, with a slash of her whip, she sends the lizardfolk flying off the end of the plank. The creature's scream ends abruptly with a splash, a flailing sound, and then silence. The gathered onlookers quickly scurry back to work.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The room contains Grabbit (see "{@footnote Lesser Pirates|Moved to the Info tab of Grabbit's bestiary entry.}"), three {@creature goblin|MM|goblins}, four {@creature lizardfolk}, and two human {@creature bandit|MM|bandits}. All disperse after the scene described above.

entries.name: Stairs & Hole
entries: The central hole spans {@area t12|t12}, where it culminates in a water-filled tank, to {@area t20|t20}. The stairs spiralling around it connect the three areas, as well as {@area t11|t11}, the interior mezzanine. Characters who fall down the hole take no damage provided they land in the water-filled tank. If the tank is drained, they take fall damage as normal.

entries.name: T2. Forecastles
entries: These areas are empty.
Four of the ships from which the lair is made poke their forecastles out above the water's surface.

entries.name: T3. Captain Scummer's Quarters
entries: The door to area t3 is locked. It can be opened with a successful DC 18 Strength check, a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or with Captain Scummer's key, found in his pocket.
Als er tekens binnenkomen, lees of parafraseer het volgende:

Behind the door is a luxurious cabin. A decorated curtain depicts a scene of beautiful elves in a pristine garden and sections off part of the chamber. Opposite the curtain is a curved, wooden desk and rocking chair.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The beautiful curtain animates as a {@creature rug of smothering} if touched by a creature other than Scummer.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The wooden desk has several draws, none of which are locked. They contain papers and maps detailing trade agreements and routes along the Sword Coast. Characters who succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discover that one drawer has a false bottom. Hidden within are 500 gp of small emeralds in a leather pouch and a vial of thick, creamy-coloured fluid. The fluid can be identified as {@item carrion crawler mucus} with a successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check (see {@book chapter 8|dmg|8|Contact|0} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Curtain
entries: Behind the curtain is a bed covered by long, silk sheets and fancy throw pillows. Characters who part the sheets and look beneath the bed find a locked box. The box can be opened with a successful DC 10 Strength check, a successful DC 16 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or with a key kept in Scummer's pocket. Opening the box with a Strength check breaks the contents. Inside are three {@item potion of greater healing|DMG|potions of greater healing} and 312 gp in assorted coinage.

Lounging atop this deck are four lizardfolk. The scaly humanoids lean against the balustrade of the deck, chewing old bones and spotting fish in the waters below. Mounted onto the wooden platform is a strange device that resembles a large ballista with a snarling reptilian face at its end.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There are four {@creature lizardfolk} atop this deck and an {@creature oaken bolter|MTF} created by Powder.
Sat at a small desk, carefully polishing a wooden wand, is a hulking brute of a sahuagin. The beastly creature has four muscled arms which cradle the wand delicately.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Dhurge|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) is here sorting through and his wands. He attacks intruders who don't knock.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: An unlocked drawer in the desk contains a {@item wand of magic detection} and a {@item wand of secrets}, as well as handwritten notes in {@language Common} about Tentrix's possible involvement with Slarkrethel, and his link to Purple Rocks.
As well as his equipment, Dhurge carries a mermaid's purse (shark egg sack) containing bright corals worth 100 gp, and 24 gp in assorted coinage.

Working atop this deck is a gnome with a shock of orange hair. She is bent low beneath a huge iron tube, belled at one end, and mounted on wheels. As she works, puffs of smoke rise into the air accompanied by pops and cracks that break through the babble of the crew. Nearby, two rough looking fellows are skimming stones off the side of the boat.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Working on one of the cannons is {@creature Luthra 'Powder' Lingenhall|CallfromtheDeep|Powder} (see "{@footnote Lesser Pirates|Moved to the Info tab of Powder's bestiary entry.}"). Standing nearby are two human {@creature bandit|MM|bandits}. Unless interrupted, Powder fixes the cannon in 10 minutes (see below) and heads to {@area t16|t16}.

entries.name: Weapons
entries: There are two {@object cannon|DMG|cannons} mounted on the deck (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). The southernmost cannon is operational, the other is malfunctioning. A creature that tries to fire the broken cannon causes it to explode, completely destroying it. Any creature within 15 feet of the cannon must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw, taking 44 ({@damage 8d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on successful one.

The cannons were created by {@creature Luthra 'Powder' Lingenhall|CallfromtheDeep|Powder}, and characters who have no experience with firearms are unlikely to have the vaguest idea how to use them without first succeeding on a DC 20 Intelligence check. The cannons require ten shots of {@item smokepowder|WDH} per discharge.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Two kegs of {@item smokepowder|WDH} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) stand nearby. As well as her equipment, Powder carries a tiny, decorated, clockwork beetle that spits sparks (250 gp), a set of {@item tinker's tools|phb} (50 gp), a {@item spyglass|phb} (1,000 gp), a key to the hidden store in {@area t16|t16}, and 65 gp in assorted coinage.

entries.name: T7. Storm Maiden's Quarters

entries: Two burly humans guard the entrance to these quarters. A woman with wild, white hair marches toward the guards from the central hub of the lair. As she approaches, the three get into a heated conversation which eventually turns to laughter. A moment later, an explosion from the poop deck above draws their attention.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The two guards are Illuskan {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} from Norland, loyal to {@creature the Storm Maiden|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), who appears on deck. The three discuss a prisoner in {@area t18|t18}. Characters who succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check overhear the conversation, which reveals the identity of the prisoner; Lady Doreena Sternquarter—a member of the Lord's Alliance. Tentrix intends to ransom her back to the Alliance for a hefty sum but has refused to send the Storm Maiden to make the trade, which has frustrated her.
After the explosion, the berserkers go to the poop deck to investigate.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as her equipment, the Storm Maiden wears a golden thundercloud pendant with three lightning bolts beneath (25 gp), a gold torc (250 gp), and an ivory bracer (25 gp).
If the characters enter the Storm Maiden's quarters proper, read or paraphrase the following:

This cabin is sparsely furnished, with almost no decoration. The only features are a crossed pair of greataxes behind a hefty wooden shield, painted with red and blue stripes, and a desk against the far wall. A wooden bed, its frame carved in a similar fashion to northlander dragonships, stands nearby.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 15 or higher hear something move beneath the bed. Attempting to hide beneath is a {@creature berbalang|MTF} named Oloc. Oloc is a spectral duplicate of its true form, which hides on the Astral Plane.

Oloc has been hired by the githyanki of Flame Fault on {@area Tuern|tuern|x} to investigate the lair. Oloc wasn't told why to investigate, only to listen for mentions of Purple Rocks and the Astral Plane. So far Oloc has discovered that Tentrix is from Purple Rocks, and is connected to a dark power there.
Oloc can cast {@spell speak with dead}, which may become useful if the characters want to extract information from a dead Tentrix, as the Sea King loses his connection with Slarkrethel when killed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: There are two {@item greataxe|phb|greataxes} and a {@item shield|phb} mounted on the wall. The desk has three copper flagons emblazoned with dragons atop it (1 gp each) as well as a bottle of fine mead (25 gp).

A large, catapult-type mechanism takes up most this small deck. Clambering around it are three goblins, two of whom attempt to grab something off the third. After a few minutes of evading the others, the goblin gives up and throws a packet toward its pursuers. As one of the goblins catches the packet, it explodes in a ball of flame and smoke, throwing three charred goblin corpses overboard. Shouts of exclamation rise from the deck below.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Characters might intervene before the three {@creature goblin|MM|goblins} blow themselves up with the packet of {@item smokepowder|WDH} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}). The explosion kills the goblins and draws the two {@creature berserker|MM|berserkers} from {@area t7|t7} to investigate. They return to {@area t7|t7} the following round.

entries.name: Weapons
entries: Despite the explosion, the {@object mangonel} (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}) is still functional. It is not manned unless the characters were spotted (see the {@area Lair Roster Table|lairtable|x}).

entries.name: T9. Desecratus Profanis's Quarters
entries: The door to area t9 is locked with an {@spell arcane lock}—only {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep|Desecratus} can open it normally. The door can be opened with a {@spell knock} spell, a successful DC 30 Strength check, or a successful DC 30 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

The door is also protected by a {@spell glyph of warding}, discoverable with a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Any creature other than Desecratus that opens the door triggers the glyph, which has the spell {@spell infernal calling|XGE} stored within it. When triggered, the spell summons Ix'thex the Indomitable, a {@creature white abishai|MTF}.
The devil bargains with the characters unless attacked. If the characters can retrieve Ix'thex's devil talisman from Desecratus and bring it to her, she gives them access to Desecratus's quarters.
If the characters gain entry to the chamber, read or paraphrase the following:

Ahead is a chamber dimly lit by purple light. Rows of humanoid skulls lead up to a dark stone dais, engraved with arcane runes, against the back wall. Serpentine forms are engraved into the walls of the cabin, their gaping, fanged maws pointing toward the raised platform.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher hear a hissing beneath the dais, and spot holes along its base. Creatures other than Desecratus who step onto the dais are attacked by a {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes} which emerges from the tiny holes.

entries.name: Light
entries: This room is dimly lit.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notice a ridge at the back of the dais. The ridge is a secret compartment which can be opened with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Inside is a {@item spellbook|phb} (containing {@spell arcane lock}, {@spell contact other plane}, {@spell glyph of warding}, and {@spell infernal calling|XGE}), a {@item black candle|CallfromtheDeep} with an illusory flame that extinguishes all nonmagical light sources in a room when snuffed, and an obsidian talisman engraved with a cobra head with ruby eyes (2,500 gp).
A brutish minotaur with a leather patch over one eye leans on a ballista, staring into the bay and grunting a sea shanty.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The {@creature minotaur} on this deck has a missing eye, giving them disadvantage on ranged attack rolls.

entries.name: Weapons
entries: The deck is outfitted with one {@object ballista} (see chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: T11. The Jolly Roger
entries: Descending the stairs from {@area t1|t1} or ascending them from {@area t12|t12} brings the characters to this mezzanine level.
Raucous laughter and the tumbling metre of poorly played instruments fills this balcony. The place is lit by chandeliers of dripping candles that cast light into the hold below.

At one end of the balcony is a recessed bar, where half a dozen humanoids slosh their grog around in tin mugs. Opposite this is a ragged three-piece band atop a table, who are thrashing out a lusty shanty. Before long, a minotaur beating out the staggering rhythm on a battered drum slips in spilt drink and barrels into a seated goblin, throwing them into the air and over the balustrade. The creature lands with a sickening crunch, and the room erupts in laughter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Hrug (NE male orc {@creature veteran}) mans the bar for three {@creature lizardfolk} and three {@creature orc|MM|orcs}. At the other end of the mezzanine four {@creature bandit|MM|bandits} and two {creature goblin|MM|goblins} clap along to a shanty being played by a {@creature minotaur}, a {@creature bandit} and a plump dwarven {@creature bard|VGM} playing an {@item instrument of the bards, doss lute|dmg|instrument of the bards: doss lute}.

entries.name: Combat
entries: Creatures in area t11 notice intruders in this area if anything falls to area t11, or if there is a loud or highly visible spell effect. The events described in area t11 occur when intruders are discovered.

Fighting in this area gives the pirates a chance to use dirty tactics, battering people with chairs, shoving creatures over the balustrade, igniting bottles of rum to throw, and swinging across the balcony via chandeliers. If characters engage in similar activities, award them with {@variantrule Inspiration}.

entries.name: Service
entries: If the characters are posing as pirates, they can grab an ale and a piece of bread for free at the bar.
The barkeep, a scarred orc named Hrug, chats to them about occurrences in the lair. He reveals that the pirate lords are meeting tomorrow to discuss an attack on Luskan.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The bar is well-stocked with half a dozen bottles of strong spirits (10 gp each). The four chandeliers hanging from the ceiling are gold-plated (100 gp each).

entries.name: T12. Hold
entries: Descending the stairs from {@area t11|t11} brings the characters to this lower level. Read or paraphrase the following:

Sunk into the centre of the lair's hold is an enormous, waterfilled tank, above which the spiral stair curves. Standing around the hold are several individuals; a man in captain's attire whose face is covered in tentacles, a lumbering toadlike humanoid, and a giant purple snake with the face of a woman. Accompanying them are a rag-tag group of pirates.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When characters enter for the first time {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep} ({@creature green slaad}), {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep} ({@creature spirit naga}), and four {@creature bandit|MM|bandits} are arguing about the Armada's next move. They cannot decide whether to attack Luskan's navy directly or send mercenaries. Tentrix favours the latter, Profanis the former.
The tank in the room contains an {@creature ogre zombie}.

entries.name: Combat
entries: If a fight breaks out in this room, it alerts the sleeping creatures in {@area t17|t17}, all of whom enter on initiative 10 the following round.

entries.name: Events
entries: If the characters are noticed the following occurs:

items: {@creature Desecratus Profanis|CallfromtheDeep|Desecratus} casts {@spell dominate person} on the first humanoid character she sees, using them to block the spiral stair. She then uses spells that don't require concentration, such as {@spell lightning bolt}, to attack the other characters. The {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} attack with their crossbows.

{@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep|Tentrix} screams insults at the characters as a {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) emerges from the hole behind him. He and {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep|Scummer} run over the beast to {@area t13|t13} where Tentrix casts {@spell flesh to stone} from a {@item spell scroll (6th level)|dmg|spell scroll}, turning the colossal octopus into stone, blocking the entrance to {@area t13|t13} after them.

entries.name: Hole
entries: There is a large hole in the deck of the hold that spans into {@area t13|t13}. Lurking beneath is a {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep} (see above). Characters can use this hole to enter or exit the lair, via the ocean, from below.

entries.name: Tank & Doors
entries: There is a 25-foot wide, 25-foot deep, 12-foot tall tank set 5-feet lower than the floor level in the centre of the hold. Inside the tank is an {@creature ogre zombie} whose eyes have been plucked from its skull, and whose body festers with multiple wounds. The ship uses the zombie as waste disposal, but also as part of a locking mechanism.

Characters who look into the tank notice pressure plates in each corner. Each of these pressure plates corresponds to the door they are directly opposite (the northwest corner to {@area t19|t19}, for example). Applying a weight of 300 lbs or more to these pressure plates compresses them, causing the matched door to unlock. Removing the weight causes the door to lock again.

The easiest way to trigger the pressure plates is to lure the ogre zombie onto them by holding 'food'; anything from {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations} to dead goblins, in the water above the plate, or by banging on the glass. The ogre remains where it has been lured until it is lured to another area of the tank.

entries.name: T13. Audience Chamber
entries: To enter this area, characters may have to clear the {@condition petrified} {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep|octopus} blocking the entrance. This can be achieved by using a {@item spell scroll (6th level)|dmg|spell scroll} of {@spell flesh to stone} (see {@area t15|t15}) or by casting {@spell dispel magic} (DC 16) upon it. Doing so causes the {@creature colossal octopus|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) to attack the characters, and allows {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and {@creature Captain Scummer|CallfromtheDeep} ({@creature green slaad}) to join the fight.

Tentrix is in command of Scummer thanks to owning its control gem. He uses Scummer to take hits, while looking for an opening to escape into the main body of the lair. Tentrix doesn't flee the lair completely, but searches for more allies he can bring into the fight.
If characters enter area t13, read or paraphrase the following:

There is little in this chamber save a throne of melted cutlasses and two tapestries with strange, otherworldly motifs stretching across them. They seem at once to depict swirling masses of dark tentacles, whirlpools of raging waves, spiralling galaxies of stars, and dark, bulbous eyes.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Although unnerving to behold, the tapestries are finely made (250 gp each). Scummer has the key to {@area t3|t3} and his lockbox in his pocket. Tentrix has the key to {@area t14|t14}, the secret store in {@area t16|t16}, and the cells in {@area t18|t18}.

entries.name: T14. Tentrix's Quarters
entries: The door to area t14 is locked. It can be opened with a successful DC 18 Strength check, a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or with a key kept in Tentrix's pocket. When characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:
